<td class="plainlist" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0">

<div class="NavContent hlist" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:center;">
<dl>
<dd><b>God / Highest Reality</b></dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/God_and_gender_in_Hinduism" title="God and gender in Hinduism">God and gender</a></li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd><b>Life</b></dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">Atman</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Maya_(illusion)" title="Maya (illusion)">Maya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">Karma</a></li>

<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purusharthas" title="Purusharthas">Purusharthas</a><br/>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd><b>Ethics</b></dd>
</dl>
<ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/Satya" title="Satya">Satya</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Compassion#Hinduism" title="Compassion">Dayā</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Akrodha" title="Akrodha">Akrodha</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%80rjava" title="Ārjava">Ārjava</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Santosha" title="Santosha">Santosha</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tapas_(Sanskrit)" title="Tapas (Sanskrit)">Tapas</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sv%C4%81dhy%C4%81ya" title="Svādhyāya">Svādhyāya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shaucha" title="Shaucha">Shaucha</a></li>

<dl>
<dd><b><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Liberation</a></b></dd>
</dl>
<ul>

<li><a href="/wiki/A._C._Bhaktivedanta_Swami_Prabhupada" title="A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada">Prabhupada</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ramakrishna" title="Ramakrishna">Ramakrishna</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ramana_Maharshi" title="Ramana Maharshi">Ramana Maharshi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bhaktisiddhanta_Sarasvati" title="Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati">Sarasvati</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sivananda_Saraswati" title="Sivananda Saraswati">Sivananda</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/U._G._Krishnamurti" title="U. G. Krishnamurti">U. G. Krishnamurti</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sai_Baba_of_Shirdi" title="Sai Baba of Shirdi">Sai Baba</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nigamananda_Paramahansa" title="Nigamananda Paramahansa">Nigamananda</a></li>

</td>

<td class="plainlist" style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_Hinduism_terms" title="Glossary of Hinduism terms">Glossary of Hinduism terms</a></li>
<li><i><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_red.svg"><img alt="Aum Om red.svg" class="noviewer" data-file-height="367" data-file-width="356" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/16px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/23px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/31px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Hinduism" title="Portal:Hinduism">Hinduism portal</a></i></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Hinduism" title="Template:Hinduism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Hinduism" title="Template talk:Hinduism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Hinduism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><b>Hinduism</b> is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_religion" title="Indian religion">Indian religion</a>, or a way of life,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-definition_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-definition-1">[note 1]</a></sup> widely practiced in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>. Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[note 2]</a></sup> and some practitioners and scholars refer to it as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī"><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</span></a></i>, "the eternal tradition," or the "eternal way," beyond human history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott19985.2C_Quote:_.22Many_describe_Hinduism_as_.27.27sanatana_dharma.27.27.2C_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_orgins_lie_beyond_human_history.22_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott19985.2C_Quote:_.22Many_describe_Hinduism_as_.27.27sanatana_dharma.27.27.2C_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_orgins_lie_beyond_human_history.22-6">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[5]</a></sup> Scholars regard Hinduism as a fusion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">[note 3]</a></sup> or synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-9">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">[note 4]</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel_2007_12_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel_2007_12-11">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fusion_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">[note 5]</a></sup> with diverse roots<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911-13">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[note 6]</a></sup> and no founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler19971.2C_7_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler19971.2C_7-15">[9]</a></sup> This "Hindu synthesis" started to develop between 500 BCE and 300 CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup> following the <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> (1500 BCE to 500 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup></p>
<p>Although Hinduism contains a broad range of philosophies, it is linked by shared concepts, recognisable rituals, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_cosmology" title="Hindu cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">shared textual resources</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites">pilgrimage to sacred sites</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">Hindu texts</a> are classified into <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aruti" title="Śruti">Śruti</a> ("heard") and <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smṛti</a> ("remembered"). These texts discuss theology, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_mythology" title="Hindu mythology">mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">agamic</a> <a href="/wiki/Ritual" title="Ritual">rituals</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">temple building</a>, among other topics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-18">[12]</a></sup> Major scriptures include the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Agamas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-20">[14]</a></sup> Sources of authority and eternal truths in its texts play an important role, but there is also a strong Hindu tradition of the questioning of this authority, to deepen the understanding of these truths and to further develop the tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazierintrop2_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-frazierintrop2-21">[15]</a></sup></p>
<p>Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include the four <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārthas</a>, the proper goals or aims of human life, namely <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> (ethics/duties), <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a> (prosperity/work), <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a> (desires/passions) and <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a> (liberation/freedom/salvation);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-22">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11-23">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> (action, intent and consequences), <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">Saṃsāra</a> (cycle of rebirth), and the various <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yogas</a> (paths or practices to attain moksha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-20">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-24">[18]</a></sup> Hindu practices include rituals such as <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">puja</a> (worship) and recitations, meditation, family-oriented <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rites of passage</a>, annual festivals, and occasional pilgrimages. Some Hindus leave their social world and material possessions, then engage in lifelong <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (monastic practices) to achieve Moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ellinger70_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-25">[19]</a></sup> Hinduism prescribes the eternal duties, such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings (<a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>), patience, forbearance, self-restraint, and compassion, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-26">[web 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[20]</a></sup> The four largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">denominations</a> of Hinduism are the <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Smarta_Tradition" title="Smarta Tradition">Smartism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[21]</a></sup></p>
<p>Hinduism is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's third largest religion</a>; its followers, known as <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindus</a>, number about <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">1.15 billion</a>, or 15-16% of the global population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[web 2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-30">[22]</a></sup> Hindus form the majority of the population in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a>. Significant Hindu communities are also found in <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">other countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[24]</a></sup></p>

</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-48"><a href="#.22Second_Urbanisation.22_.28c._500.E2.80.93200_BCE.29"><span class="tocnumber">10.5</span> <span class="toctext">"Second Urbanisation" (c. 500–200 BCE)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-49"><a href="#Classical_Hinduism_.28c._200_BCE_.E2.80.93_1100_CE.29"><span class="tocnumber">10.6</span> <span class="toctext">Classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE – 1100 CE)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-50"><a href="#Islamic_rule_and_Bhakti_movement_of_Hinduism_.28c._1200.E2.80.931750_CE.29"><span class="tocnumber">10.7</span> <span class="toctext">Islamic rule and Bhakti movement of Hinduism (c. 1200–1750 CE)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-51"><a href="#Modern_Hinduism_.28from_circa_1800.29"><span class="tocnumber">10.8</span> <span class="toctext">Modern Hinduism (from circa 1800)</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-52"><a href="#Hindu_revivalism"><span class="tocnumber">10.8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Hindu revivalism</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-53"><a href="#Popularity_in_the_west"><span class="tocnumber">10.8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Popularity in the west</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-57"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>

</div>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a></div>
<p>The word <i>Hindu</i> is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20083_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20083-33">[25]</a></sup>/<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup> root <i>Sindhu</i>, the Indo-Aryan name for the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> in the northwestern part of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> (modern day Pakistan and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_India" title="Northern India">Northern India</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[note 7]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Gavin Flood</a>, "The actual term 'Hindu' first occurs as a <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: <i>Sindhu</i>)",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup> more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of <a href="/wiki/Darius_I" title="Darius I">Darius I</a> (550–486 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh-36">[27]</a></sup> The term <i>Hindu</i> in these ancient records is a geographical term and did not refer to a religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup> Among the earliest known records of 'Hindu' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th-century CE Chinese text <i>Record of the Western Regions</i> by <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh-36">[27]</a></sup> and 14th-century Persian text <i>Futuhu's-salatin</i> by 'Abd al-Malik <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isami_(historian)" title="Isami (historian)">Isami</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[note 8]</a></sup></p>
<p>Thapar states that the word <i>Hindu</i> is found as <i>heptahindu</i> in <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a> – equivalent to Rigvedic <i>sapta sindhu</i>, while <i>hndstn</i> (pronounced <i>Hindustan</i>) is found in a <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian</a> inscription from the 3rd century CE, both of which refer to parts of northwestern South Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[35]</a></sup> The Arabic term <i>al-Hind</i> referred to the people who live across the River Indus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar199377_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar199377-46">[36]</a></sup> This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre-Islamic Persian term <i>Hindū</i>, which refers to all Indians. By the 13th century, <i><a href="/wiki/Hindustan" title="Hindustan">Hindustan</a></i> emerged as a popular alternative <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Names_of_India" title="Names of India">name of India</a>, meaning the "land of Hindus".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884-47">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[note 9]</a></sup></p>
<p>The term <i>Hindu</i> was later used occasionally in some Sanskrit texts such as the later <i><a href="/wiki/Rajatarangini" title="Rajatarangini">Rajataranginis</a></i> of Kashmir (Hinduka, c. 1450) and some 16th- to 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> <a href="/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavism" title="Gaudiya Vaishnavism">Gaudiya Vaishnava</a> texts including <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Charitamrita" title="Chaitanya Charitamrita">Chaitanya Charitamrita</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Bhagavata" title="Chaitanya Bhagavata">Chaitanya Bhagavata</a></i>. These texts used it to distinguish Hindus from Muslims who are called <a href="/wiki/Yona#Later_meanings" title="Yona">Yavanas</a> (foreigners) or <a href="/wiki/Mleccha" title="Mleccha">Mlecchas</a> (barbarians), with the 16th-century <i>Chaitanya Charitamrita</i> text and the 17th century <i>Bhakta Mala</i> text using the phrase "<i>Hindu dharma</i>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[38]</a></sup> It was only towards the end of the 18th century that European merchants and colonists began to refer to the followers of Indian religions collectively as <i>Hindus</i>. The term <i>Hinduism</i>, then spelled <i>Hindooism</i>, was introduced into the English language in the 18th-century to denote the religious, philosophical, and cultural traditions native to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[39]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions">Definitions</span></h2>
<p>Hinduism includes a diversity of ideas on <a href="/wiki/Spirituality#Hinduism" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a> and traditions, but has no ecclesiastical order, no unquestionable religious authorities, no governing body, no prophet(s) nor any binding holy book; Hindus can choose to be polytheistic, pantheistic, monotheistic, monistic, agnostic, atheistic or humanist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[42]</a></sup> Because of the wide range of traditions and ideas covered by the term Hinduism, arriving at a comprehensive definition is difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup> The religion "defies our desire to define and categorize it".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[43]</a></sup> Hinduism has been variously defined as a religion, a religious tradition, a set of religious beliefs, and "a way of life."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200312-13_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200312-13-55">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-definition_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-definition-1">[note 1]</a></sup> From a Western lexical standpoint, Hinduism like other faiths is appropriately referred to as a religion. In India the term <i>dharma</i> is preferred, which is broader than the western term <i>religion</i>.</p>
<p>The study of India and its cultures and religions, and the definition of "Hinduism", has been shaped by the interests of colonialism and by Western notions of religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[45]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, those influences and its outcomes have been the topic of debate among scholars of Hinduism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman2004_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman2004-57">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[note 10]</a></sup> and have also been taken over by critics of the Western view on India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009-59">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[note 11]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Typology">Typology</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="507" data-file-width="512" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/220px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/330px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/440px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">AUM</a>, a stylised letter of <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script, used as a religious symbol in Hinduism</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Hinduism as it is commonly known can be subdivided into a number of major currents. Of the historical division into six <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Darsanas" title="Darsanas">darsanas</a> (philosophies), two schools, <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>, are currently the most prominent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[48]</a></sup> Classified by primary deity or deities, four major Hinduism modern currents are <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva), <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Devi) and <a href="/wiki/Smarta_Tradition" title="Smarta Tradition">Smartism</a> (five deities treated as same).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENath200131_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENath200131-62">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113.2C_154_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113.2C_154-63">[50]</a></sup> Hinduism also accepts numerous divine beings, with many Hindus considering the deities to be aspects or manifestations of a single impersonal absolute or ultimate reality or God, while some Hindus maintain that a specific deity represents the supreme and various deities are lower manifestations of this supreme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199614_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199614-64">[51]</a></sup> Other notable characteristics include a belief in existence of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātman</a> (soul, self), <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">reincarnation</a> of one's ātman, and karma as well as a belief in dharma (duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and right way of living).</p>
<p>McDaniel (2007) classifies Hinduism into six major kinds and numerous minor kinds, in order to understand expression of emotions among the Hindus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-65">[52]</a></sup> The major kinds, according to McDaniel are, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_Hinduism" title="Folk Hinduism">Folk Hinduism</a>, based on local traditions and cults of local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deities" title="Deities">deities</a> and is the oldest, non-literate system; <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic Hinduism</a> based on the earliest layers of the Vedas traceable to 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, emphasizing knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Yoga Sutras of Patanjali</a> emphasizing introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a> or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-65">[52]</a></sup></p>
<p>Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions and four forms of Hindu religiosity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421-66">[53]</a></sup> The three Hindu religions are "Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism,", "folk religions and tribal religions," and "founded religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422-67">[54]</a></sup> The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "karma-marga",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-68">[55]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">jnana-marga</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-69">[56]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_yoga" title="Bhakti yoga">bhakti-marga</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-69">[56]</a></sup> and "heroism," which is rooted in <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa#Warrior_ascetics" title="Sannyasa">militaristic traditions</a>, such as Ramaism and parts of political Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-68">[55]</a></sup> This is also called <a href="/wiki/V%C4%ABrya_(Hinduism)" title="Vīrya (Hinduism)">virya-marga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_69-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-69">[56]</a></sup> According to Michaels, one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to one or both of the Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism and Folk religion typology, whether practicing or non-practicing. He classifies most Hindus as belonging by choice to one of the "founded religions" such as Vaishnavism and Shaivism that are salvation-focussed and often de-emphasize Brahman priestly authority yet incorporate ritual grammar of Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421-22_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421-22-70">[57]</a></sup> He includes among "founded religions" Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism that are now distinct religions, syncretic movements such as <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>, as well as various "Guru-isms" and new religious movements such as <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISKCON" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422-23_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422-23-71">[58]</a></sup></p>
<p>Inden states that the attempt to classify Hinduism by typology started in the imperial times, when proselytizing missionaries and colonial officials sought to understand and portray Hinduism from their interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-72">[59]</a></sup> Hinduism was construed as emanating not from a reason of spirit but fantasy and creative imagination, not conceptual but symbolical, not ethical but emotive, not rational or spiritual but of cognitive mysticism. This stereotype followed and fit, states Inden, with the imperial imperatives of the era, providing the moral justification for the colonial project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-72">[59]</a></sup> From tribal Animism to Buddhism, everything was subsumed as part of Hinduism. The early reports set the tradition and scholarly premises for typology of Hinduism, as well as the major assumptions and flawed presuppositions that has been at the foundation of Indology. Hinduism, according to Inden, has been neither what imperial religionists stereotyped it to be, nor is it appropriate to equate Hinduism to be merely monist pantheism and philosophical idealism of Advaita Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_72-2"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-72">[59]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_understanding">Indigenous understanding</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Sanātana_Dharma"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="San.C4.81tana_Dharma"><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</span></span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī">Sanātanī</a></div>
<p>To its adherents, Hinduism is a traditional way of life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[60]</a></sup> Many practitioners refer to the "orthodox" form of Hinduism as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī"><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</span></a></i>, "the eternal law" or the "eternal way".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[61]</a></sup> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101-75">[62]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> word <i>dharma</i> has a much deeper meaning than <i><a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religion</a></i> and is not its equivalent. All aspects of a Hindu life, namely acquiring wealth (artha), fulfillment of desires (kama), and attaining liberation (moksha) are part of dharma which encapsulates the "right way of living" and eternal harmonious principles in their fulfillment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[64]</a></sup></p>
<p><i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</span></i> refers to the "eternal" duties all Hindus have to follow, regardless of class, caste, or sect, such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings, purity, goodwill, mercy, patience, forbearance, self-restraint, generosity, and asceticism. This is contrasted with <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita#Svadharma_and_svabhava" title="Bhagavad Gita">svadharma</a>, one's "own duty", the duties to be followed by members of a specific <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varna</a> and <a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti" title="Jāti">jāti</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-26">[web 1]</a></sup> According to Knott, this also</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>... refers to the idea that its origins lie beyond human history, and its truths have been divinely revealed (Shruti) and passed down through the ages to the present day in the most ancient of the world's scriptures, the Veda. (<a href="#CITEREFKnott1998">Knott 1998</a>, p. 5)</p>
</blockquote>
<p>According to the Encyclopædia Britannica,</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>The term has also more recently been used by Hindu leaders, reformers, and nationalists to refer to Hinduism as a unified world religion. Sanatana dharma has thus become a synonym for the "eternal" truth and teachings of Hinduism, the latter conceived of as not only transcendent of history and unchanging but also as indivisible and ultimately nonsectarian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_26-2"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-26">[web 1]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_modernism">Hindu modernism</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="933" height="302" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/220px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/330px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/440px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Swami Vivekananda</a> was a key figure in introducing Vedanta and Yoga in Europe and the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600-78">[65]</a></sup> raising interfaith awareness and making Hinduism a world religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209-79">[66]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a></div>
<p>Beginning in the 19th century, Indian modernists re-asserted Hinduism as a major asset of Indian civilisation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup> meanwhile "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-81">[68]</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Western stereotypes were reversed, emphasizing the universal aspects, and introducing modern approaches of social problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup> This approach had a great appeal, not only in India, but also in the west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup> Major representatives of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">"Hindu modernism"</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-82">[69]</a></sup> are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_Rammohan_Roy" title="Raja Rammohan Roy">Raja Rammohan Roy</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vivekananda" title="Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256-261_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256-261-83">[70]</a></sup></p>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_Rammohan_Roy" title="Raja Rammohan Roy">Raja Rammohan Roy</a> is known as the father of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_Renaissance" title="Hindu Renaissance">Hindu Renaissance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hindu1_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-hindu1-84">[71]</a></sup> He was a major influence on Swami Vivekananda (1863–1902), who, according to Flood, was "a figure of great importance in the development of a modern Hindu self-understanding and in formulating the West's view of Hinduism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257-85">[72]</a></sup> Central to his philosophy is the idea that the divine exists in all beings, that all human beings can achieve union with this "innate divinity",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-82">[69]</a></sup> and that seeing this divine as the essence of others will further love and social harmony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_82-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-82">[69]</a></sup> According to Vivekananda, there is an essential unity to Hinduism, which underlies the diversity of its many forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_82-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-82">[69]</a></sup> According to Flood, Vivekananda's vision of Hinduism "is one generally accepted by most English-speaking middle-class Hindus today."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259-86">[73]</a></sup> Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan sought to reconcile western rationalism with Hinduism, "presenting Hinduism as an essentially rationalistic and humanistic religious experience."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249-87">[74]</a></sup></p>
<p>This "Global Hinduism"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-88">[75]</a></sup> has a worldwide appeal, transcending national boundaries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-88">[75]</a></sup> and, according to Flood, "becoming a world religion alongside Christianity, Islam and Buddhism",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_88-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-88">[75]</a></sup> both for the Hindu diaspora communities and for westerners who are attracted to non-western cultures and religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_88-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-88">[75]</a></sup> It emphasizes universal spiritual values such as social justice, peace and "the spiritual transformation of humanity."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_88-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-88">[75]</a></sup> It has developed partly due to "re-enculturation",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-89">[76]</a></sup> or the <a href="/wiki/Pizza_effect" title="Pizza effect">Pizza effect</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_89-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-89">[76]</a></sup> in which elements of Hindu culture have been exported to the West, gaining popularity there, and as a consequence also gained greater popularity in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_89-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-89">[76]</a></sup> This globalization of Hindu culture brought "to the West teachings which have become an important cultural force in western societies, and which in turn have become an important cultural force in India, their place of origin."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-268_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-268-90">[77]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_understanding">Western understanding</span></h3>
<p>Western scholars regard Hinduism as a fusion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">[note 3]</a></sup> or synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">[note 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-9">[6]</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel_2007_12_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel_2007_12-11">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fusion_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">[note 5]</a></sup> which emerged after the Vedic period, between 500<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup>-200<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup> the beginning of the "Epic and Puranic" c.q. "Preclassical" period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup></p>
<p>Hinduism's tolerance to variations in belief and its broad range of traditions make it difficult to define as a religion according to traditional Western conceptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1996-A275_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1996-A275-96">[80]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some academics suggest that Hinduism can be seen as a category with "fuzzy edges" rather than as a well-defined and rigid entity. Some forms of religious expression are central to Hinduism and others, while not as central, still remain within the category. Based on this idea Ferro-Luzzi has developed a 'Prototype Theory approach' to the definition of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[81]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity_and_unity">Diversity and unity</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity">Diversity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<p>Hinduism has been described as a tradition having a "complex, organic, multileveled and sometimes internally inconsistent nature."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger2000434_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger2000434-98">[82]</a></sup> Hinduism does not have a "unified system of belief encoded in a declaration of faith or a <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creed</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_34-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-34">[26]</a></sup> but is rather an umbrella term comprising the plurality of religious phenomena of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[83]</a></sup> According to the Supreme Court of India,</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>Unlike other religions in the World, the Hindu religion does not claim any one Prophet, it does not worship any one God, it does not believe in any one philosophic concept, it does not follow any one act of religious rites or performances; in fact, it does not satisfy the traditional features of a religion or creed. It is a way of life and nothing more".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[84]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Part of the problem with a single definition of the term <i>Hinduism</i> is the fact that Hinduism does not have a founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[85]</a></sup> It is a synthesis of various traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[86]</a></sup> the "Brahmanical orthopraxy, the renouncer traditions and popular or local traditions."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_93-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-93">[78]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some Hindu philosophies postulate a <a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">theistic</a> <a href="/wiki/Ontology" title="Ontology">ontology</a> of creation, of sustenance, and of the destruction of the universe, yet <a href="/wiki/Atheism_in_Hinduism" title="Atheism in Hinduism">some Hindus are atheists</a>, as they view Hinduism more as philosophy than religion.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sense_of_unity">Sense of unity</span></h3>
<p>Despite the differences, there is also a sense of unity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-103">[87]</a></sup> Most Hindu traditions revere a body of religious or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sastra" title="Sastra">sacred literature</a>, the Vedas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-104">[88]</a></sup> although there are exceptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199635_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199635-105">[89]</a></sup> These texts are a reminder of the ancient cultural heritage and point of pride for Hindus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-106">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[91]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Louis_Renou" title="Louis Renou">Louis Renou</a> stating that "even in the most orthodox domains, the reverence to the Vedas has come to be a simple raising of the hat".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_106-1"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-106">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911-108">[92]</a></sup></p>
<p>Halbfass states that, although Shaivism and Vaishaism may be regarded as "self-contained religious constellations",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-103">[87]</a></sup> there is a degree of interaction and reference between the "theoreticians and literary representatives"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-103">[87]</a></sup> of each tradition which indicates the presence of "a wider sense of identity, a sense of coherence in a shared context and of inclusion in a common framework and horizon".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_103-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-103">[87]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_developments">Indigenous developments</span></h4>
<p>The notion of common denominators for several religions and traditions of India was already noted from the 12th century CE on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[93]</a></sup> Lorenzen traces the emergence of a "family resemblance", and what he calls as "beginnings of medieval and modern Hinduism" taking shape, at c. 300-600 CE, with the development of the early Puranas, and continuities with the earlier Vedic religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636-110">[94]</a></sup> Lorenzen states that the establishment of a Hindu self-identity took place "through a process of mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim Other."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-111">[95]</a></sup> According to Lorenzen, this "presence of the Other"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-111">[95]</a></sup> is necessary to recognise the "loose family resemblance" among the various traditions and schools,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648.2C655_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648.2C655-112">[96]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th centuries "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the "six systems" (<i>saddarsana</i>) of mainstream Hindu philosophy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson20102_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson20102-113">[97]</a></sup> The tendency of "a blurring of philosophical distinctions" has also been noted by Burley.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurley200734_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurley200734-114">[98]</a></sup> Hacker called this "inclusivism"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-104">[88]</a></sup> and Michaels speaks of "the identificatory habit".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-18">[12]</a></sup> Lorenzen locates the origins of a distinct Hindu identity in the interaction between Muslims and Hindus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624-33_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624-33-115">[99]</a></sup> and a process of "mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim other",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627-116">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[note 12]</a></sup> which started well before 1800.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626-27_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626-27-118">[101]</a></sup> Michaels notes:</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>As a counteraction to Islamic supremacy and as part of the continuing process of regionalization, two religious innovations developed in the Hindu religions: the formation of sects and a historicization which preceded later nationalism [...] [S]aints and sometimes militant sect leaders, such as the Marathi poet Tukaram (1609-1649) and Ramdas (1608-1681), articulated ideas in which they glorified Hinduism and the past. The Brahmins also produced increasingly historical texts, especially eulogies and chronicles of sacred sites (Mahatmyas), or developed a reflexive passion for collecting and compiling extensive collections of quotations on various subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444-119">[102]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<p>This inclusivism<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[103]</a></sup> was further developed in the 19th and 20th centuries by <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">Neo-Vedanta</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2001_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2001-121">[104]</a></sup> and has become characteristic of modern Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_104-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-104">[88]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_influences">Colonial influences</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">Orientalism</a></div>
<p>The notion and reports on "Hinduism" as a "single world religious tradition"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100-102_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100-102-122">[105]</a></sup> was popularised by 19th-century proselytizing missionaries and European Indologists, roles sometimes served by the same person, who relied on texts preserved by Brahmins (priests) for their information of Indian religions, and animist observations which the missionary Orientalists presumed was Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100-102_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100-102-122">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_72-3"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-72">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200414-15_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200414-15-123">[106]</a></sup> These reports influenced perceptions about Hinduism. Some scholars<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="Who says this? (April 2017)">weasel words</span></a></i>]</sup> state that the colonial polemical reports led to fabricated stereotypes where Hinduism was mere mystic paganism devoted to the service of devils,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[note 13]</a></sup> while other scholars state that the colonial constructions influenced the belief that the <i>Vedas</i>, <i>Bhagavad Gita</i>, <i>Manusmriti</i> and such texts were the essence of Hindu religiosity, and in the modern association of 'Hindu doctrine' with the schools of Vedanta (in particular Advaita Vedanta) as paradigmatic example of Hinduism's mystical nature".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999169_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999169-126">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[note 14]</a></sup> Pennington, while concurring that the study of Hinduism as a world religion began in the colonial era, disagrees that Hinduism is a colonial European era invention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brianpennington5_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-brianpennington5-137">[115]</a></sup> He states that the shared theology, common ritual grammar and way of life of those who identify themselves as Hindus is traceable to ancient times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brianpennington5_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-brianpennington5-137">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[note 15]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beliefs">Beliefs</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/200px-Halebid3.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/300px-Halebid3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/400px-Halebid3.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Temple wall panel relief sculpture at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoysaleswara_temple" title="Hoysaleswara temple">Hoysaleswara temple</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Halebidu" title="Halebidu">Halebidu</a>, representing the <a href="/wiki/Trimurti" title="Trimurti">Trimurti</a>: <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include (but are not restricted to) Dharma (ethics/duties), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara" title="Samsara"><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Samsāra</span></a> (the continuing cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth), Karma (action, intent and consequences), Moksha (liberation from samsara or liberation in this life), and the various Yogas (paths or practices).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-24">[18]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Purusharthas_(objectives_of_human_life)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Purusharthas_.28objectives_of_human_life.29">Purusharthas (objectives of human life)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purusharthas" title="Purusharthas">Purusharthas</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Initiation_in_Hinduism" title="Initiation in Hinduism">Initiation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kāma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Moksha#Hinduism" title="Moksha">Mokṣa</a></div>
<p>Classical Hindu thought accepts four proper goals or aims of human life: <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a>. These are known as the <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārthas</a>:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-22">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11-23">[17]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span id="Dharma_(righteousness,_ethics)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dharma_.28righteousness.2C_ethics.29">Dharma (righteousness, ethics)</span></h4>
<p>Dharma is considered the foremost goal of a human being in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[122]</a></sup> The concept Dharma includes behaviors that are considered to be in accord with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rta" title="Rta">rta</a>, the order that makes life and universe possible,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[123]</a></sup> and includes duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and "right way of living".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tce_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-tce-147">[124]</a></sup> Hindu Dharma includes the religious duties, moral rights and duties of each individual, as well as behaviors that enable social order, right conduct, and those that are virtuous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tce_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-tce-147">[124]</a></sup> Dharma, according to <a href="/wiki/J._A._B._van_Buitenen" title="J. A. B. van Buitenen">Van Buitenen</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-148">[125]</a></sup> is that which all existing beings must accept and respect to sustain harmony and order in the world. It is, states Van Buitenen, the pursuit and execution of one's nature and true calling, thus playing one's role in cosmic concert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_148-1"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-148">[125]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka" title="Brihadaranyaka">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a> states it as:</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>Nothing is higher than Dharma. The weak overcomes the stronger by Dharma, as over a king. Truly that Dharma is the Truth (<i>Satya</i>); Therefore, when a man speaks the Truth, they say, "He speaks the Dharma"; and if he speaks Dharma, they say, "He speaks the Truth!" For both are one.</p>
<div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka_Upanishad" title="Brihadaranyaka Upanishad">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a>, 1.4.xiv <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[127]</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> defines dharma as upholding both this-worldly and other-worldly affairs. (Mbh 12.110.11). The word <i>Sanātana</i> means <i>eternal</i>, <i>perennial</i>, or <i>forever</i>; thus, <i>Sanātana Dharma</i> signifies that it is the dharma that has neither beginning nor end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[128]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span id="Artha_(livelihood,_wealth)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Artha_.28livelihood.2C_wealth.29">Artha (livelihood, wealth)</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a></div>
<p>Artha is objective and virtuous pursuit of wealth for livelihood, obligations and economic prosperity. It is inclusive of political life, diplomacy and material well-being. The Artha concept includes all "means of life", activities and resources that enables one to be in a state one wants to be in, wealth, career and financial security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-johnk_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-johnk-152">[129]</a></sup> The proper pursuit of artha is considered an important aim of human life in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bruces_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-bruces-154">[131]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span id="Kāma_(sensual_pleasure)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="K.C4.81ma_.28sensual_pleasure.29">Kāma (sensual pleasure)</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a></div>
<p>Kāma (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>; <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>: काम) means desire, wish, passion, longing, pleasure of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senses" title="Senses">senses</a>, the aesthetic enjoyment of life, affection, or love, with or without sexual connotations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmwse_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmwse-156">[133]</a></sup> In Hinduism, Kama is considered an essential and healthy goal of human life when pursued without sacrificing Dharma, Artha and Moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[134]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span id="Mokṣa_(liberation,_freedom_from_samsara)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mok.E1.B9.A3a_.28liberation.2C_freedom_from_samsara.29">Mokṣa (liberation, freedom from samsara)</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a></div>
<p>Moksha (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa" xml:lang="sa">मोक्ष</span> <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">mokṣa</span></i>) or <b>mukti</b> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa" xml:lang="sa">मुक्ति</span>) is the ultimate, most important goal in Hinduism. In one sense, Moksha is a concept associated with liberation from sorrow, suffering and saṃsāra (birth-rebirth cycle). A release from this eschatological cycle, in after life, particularly in theistic schools of Hinduism is called moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[136]</a></sup> In other schools of Hinduism, such as monistic, moksha is a goal achievable in current life, as a state of bliss through self-realization, of comprehending the nature of one's soul, of freedom and of "realizing the whole universe as the Self".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360-160">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[138]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Karma_and_samsara">Karma and samsara</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">Karma</a></div>
<p><i>Karma</i> translates literally as <i>action</i>, <i>work</i>, or <i>deed</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[139]</a></sup> and also refers to a Vedic theory of "moral law of cause and effect".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[141]</a></sup> The theory is a combination of (1) causality that may be ethical or non-ethical; (2) ethicization, that is good or bad actions have consequences; and (3) rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wdointro_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-165">[142]</a></sup> Karma theory is interpreted as explaining the present circumstances of an individual with reference to his or her actions in past. These actions may be those in a person's current life, or, in some schools of Hinduism, possibly actions in their past lives; furthermore, the consequences may result in current life, or a person's future lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wdointro_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-165">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[143]</a></sup> This cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth is called <i>samsara</i>. Liberation from samsara through moksha is believed to ensure lasting happiness and peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[145]</a></sup> Hindu scriptures teach that the future is both a function of current human effort derived from free will and past human actions that set the circumstances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[146]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Moksha">Moksha</span></h3>
<p>The ultimate goal of life, referred to as <i>moksha</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a></i> or <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi" title="Samādhi">samadhi</a></i>, is understood in several different ways: as the realization of one's union with God; as the realization of one's eternal relationship with God; realization of the unity of all existence; perfect unselfishness and knowledge of the Self; as the attainment of perfect mental peace; and as detachment from worldly desires. Such realization liberates one from samsara, thereby ending the cycle of rebirth, sorrow and suffering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[148]</a></sup> Due to belief in the indestructibility of the soul,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[149]</a></sup> death is deemed insignificant with respect to the cosmic self.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[150]</a></sup></p>
<p>The meaning of <i>moksha</i> differs among the various Hindu schools of thought. For example, Advaita Vedanta holds that after attaining moksha a person knows their "soul, self" and identifies it as one with Brahman and everyone in all respects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-174">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-175">[152]</a></sup> The followers of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> (dualistic) schools, in moksha state, identify individual "soul, self" as distinct from Brahman but infinitesimally close, and after attaining moksha expect to spend eternity in a <a href="/wiki/Loka" title="Loka">loka</a> (heaven). To theistic schools of Hinduism, moksha is liberation from samsara, while for other schools such as the monistic school, moksha is possible in current life and is a psychological concept. According to Deutsche, moksha is transcendental consciousness to the latter, the perfect state of being, of self-realization, of freedom and of "realizing the whole universe as the Self".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360-160">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-174">[151]</a></sup> <i>Moksha</i> in these schools of Hinduism, suggests <a href="/wiki/Klaus_Klostermaier" title="Klaus Klostermaier">Klaus Klostermaier</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-175">[152]</a></sup> implies a setting free of hitherto fettered faculties, a removing of obstacles to an unrestricted life, permitting a person to be more truly a person in the full sense; the concept presumes an unused human potential of creativity, compassion and understanding which had been blocked and shut out. Moksha is more than liberation from life-rebirth cycle of suffering (samsara); Vedantic school separates this into two: jivanmukti (liberation in this life) and videhamukti (liberation after death).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[154]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_of_God">Concept of God</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a> and <a href="/wiki/God_in_Hinduism" title="God in Hinduism">God in Hinduism</a></div>
<p>Hinduism is a diverse system of thought with beliefs spanning <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panentheism" title="Panentheism">panentheism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_views_on_Pantheism" title="Hindu views on Pantheism">pantheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pandeism" title="Pandeism">pandeism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monism" title="Monism">monism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Atheism_in_Hinduism" title="Atheism in Hinduism">atheism</a> among others;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[156]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EBpolytheism_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-EBpolytheism-180">[web 3]</a></sup> and its concept of God is complex and depends upon each individual and the tradition and philosophy followed. It is sometimes referred to as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Henotheistic" title="Henotheistic">henotheistic</a> (i.e., involving devotion to a single god while accepting the existence of others), but any such term is an overgeneralization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heno_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-heno-181">[157]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Nasadiya_Sukta" title="Nasadiya Sukta">Nasadiya Sukta</a></i> (<i>Creation Hymn</i>) of the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rig_Veda" title="Rig Veda">Rig Veda</a></i> is one of the earliest texts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226-182">[158]</a></sup> which "demonstrates a sense of metaphysical speculation" about what created the universe, the concept of god(s) and The One, and whether even The One knows how the universe came into being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3translations_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-3translations-184">[160]</a></sup> The <i>Rig Veda</i> praises various deities, none superior nor inferior, in a henotheistic manner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[161]</a></sup> The hymns repeatedly refer to One Truth and Reality. The "One Truth" of Vedic literature, in modern era scholarship, has been interpreted as monotheism, monism, as well as a deified Hidden Principles behind the great happenings and processes of nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[162]</a></sup></p>
<table class="infobox" style="width:22em">
<caption><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Gods and Goddesses</a> in Hinduism</caption>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<table style="border-collapse:collapse;text-align:center;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;margin:auto;width:200px">
<tr style="vertical-align:top">
<td style="width:100px;text-align:center;:">
<div style="display:table-cell;vertical-align:middle;width:100px;height:120px;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto"><a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva"><img alt="Shiva" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/MurudeshwarStatue.JPG/90px-MurudeshwarStatue.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/MurudeshwarStatue.JPG/135px-MurudeshwarStatue.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/MurudeshwarStatue.JPG/180px-MurudeshwarStatue.JPG 2x" width="90"/></a></div>

</td>
<td style="width:100px;text-align:center;:">
<div style="display:table-cell;vertical-align:middle;width:100px;height:120px;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto"><a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga"><img alt="Durga" data-file-height="3069" data-file-width="1973" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/77px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/116px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/154px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG 2x" width="77"/></a></div>
