<tr style="vertical-align:top">
<td style="width:100px;text-align:center;:">
<div style="display:table-cell;vertical-align:middle;width:100px;height:120px;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto"><a href="/wiki/Lakshmi" title="Lakshmi"><img alt="Lakshmi" data-file-height="581" data-file-width="421" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/87px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/130px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/174px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 2x" width="87"/></a></div>
<div style="padding:1px"></div>
</td>
<td style="width:100px;text-align:center;:">
<div style="display:table-cell;vertical-align:middle;width:100px;height:120px;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto"><a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu"><img alt="Vishnu" data-file-height="3167" data-file-width="2043" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/77px-God_Vishnu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/116px-God_Vishnu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/155px-God_Vishnu.jpg 2x" width="77"/></a></div>
<div style="padding:1px"></div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Hindus believe that all living creatures have a soul. This soul – the spirit or true "self" of every person, is called the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" title="Atman (Hinduism)">ātman</a></i>. The soul is believed to be eternal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-monierwilliams2037_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-monierwilliams2037-187">[163]</a></sup> According to the monistic/pantheistic (<a href="/wiki/Nondualism" title="Nondualism">non-dualist</a>) theologies of Hinduism (such as <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a> school), this Atman is indistinct from <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>, the supreme spirit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential-188">[164]</a></sup> The goal of life, according to the Advaita school, is to realise that one's soul is identical to supreme soul, that the supreme soul is present in everything and everyone, all life is interconnected and there is oneness in all life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[167]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dualistic" title="Dualistic">Dualistic</a> schools (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a>) understand Brahman as a Supreme Being separate from individual souls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-192">[168]</a></sup> They worship the Supreme Being variously as <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a>, depending upon the sect. God is called <i><a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavan" title="Bhagavan">Bhagavan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Parameshwara_(God)" title="Parameshwara (God)">Parameshwara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Deva</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a></i>, and these terms have different meanings in different schools of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_Sanskrit_dict._195-0"><a href="#cite_note-MW_Sanskrit_dict.-195">[171]</a></sup></p>
<p>Hindu texts accept a polytheistic framework, but this is generally conceptualized as the divine essence or luminosity that gives vitality and animation to the inanimate natural substances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-196">[172]</a></sup> There is a divine in everything, human beings, animals, trees and rivers. It is observable in offerings to rivers, trees, tools of one's work, animals and birds, rising sun, friends and guests, teachers and parents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_196-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-196">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[174]</a></sup> It is the divine in these that makes each sacred and worthy of reverence. This seeing divinity in everything, state Buttimer and Wallin, makes the Vedic foundations of Hinduism quite distinct from <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">Animism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_196-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-196">[172]</a></sup> The animistic premise sees multiplicity, power differences and competition between man and man, man and animal, as well as man and nature. The Vedic view does not see this competition, rather sees a unifying divinity that connects everyone and everything.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_196-3"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-196">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[176]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Hindu scriptures refer to celestial entities called <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Devas</a></i> (or <i><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi"><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">devī</span></a></i> in feminine form; <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">devatā</span></i> used synonymously for <i>Deva</i> in Hindi), which may be translated into English as <i>gods</i> or <i>heavenly beings</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[note 16]</a></sup> The devas are an integral part of Hindu culture and are depicted in art, architecture and through <a href="/wiki/Icon" title="Icon">icons</a>, and stories about them are related in the scriptures, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">Indian epic poetry</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>. They are, however, often distinguished from <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a>, a personal god, with many Hindus worshipping Ishvara in one of its particular manifestations as their <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%ADa_devat%C4%81" title="Iṣṭa devatā">iṣṭa devatā</a></span></i>, or chosen ideal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner20059.2C_15.2C_49.2C_54.2C_86_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner20059.2C_15.2C_49.2C_54.2C_86-202">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[178]</a></sup> The choice is a matter of individual preference,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harman1_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-204">[179]</a></sup> and of regional and family traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harman1_204-1"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-204">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[note 17]</a></sup> The multitude of Devas are considered as manifestations of Brahman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avatars_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-207">[note 18]</a></sup></p>
<p>The word <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatar</a></i> does not appear in the Vedic literature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[181]</a></sup> but appears in verb forms in post-Vedic literature, and as a noun particularly in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purana" title="Purana">Puranic</a> literature after the 6th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[182]</a></sup> Theologically, the reincarnation idea is most often associated with the <i>avatars</i> of Hindu god <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, though the idea has been applied to other deities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[183]</a></sup> Varying lists of avatars of Vishnu appear in Hindu scriptures, including the ten <a href="/wiki/Dashavatara" title="Dashavatara">Dashavatara</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Garuda_Purana" title="Garuda Purana">Garuda Purana</a></i> and the twenty-two avatars in the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a></i>, though the latter adds that the incarnations of Vishnu are innumerable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[184]</a></sup> The avatars of Vishnu are important in <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> theology. In the goddess-based <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> tradition of Hinduism, avatars of the <a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a> are found and all goddesses are considered to be different aspects of the same metaphysical Brahman<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[185]</a></sup> and Shakti (energy).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[187]</a></sup> While avatars of other deities such as <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> are also mentioned in medieval Hindu texts, this is minor and occasional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[188]</a></sup></p>
<p>Both theistic and atheistic ideas, for epistemological and metaphysical reasons, are profuse in different schools of Hinduism. The early <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a> school of Hinduism, for example, was non-theist/atheist,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[189]</a></sup> but later Nyaya school scholars argued that God exists and offered proofs using its theory of logic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw-218">[191]</a></sup> Other schools disagreed with Nyaya scholars. <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[192]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimamsa" title="Mimamsa">Mimamsa</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[193]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carvaka" title="Carvaka">Carvaka</a> schools of Hinduism, were non-theist/atheist, arguing that "God was an unnecessary metaphysical assumption".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-samkhyaatheism_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-samkhyaatheism-221">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[web 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[195]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a> school started as another non-theistic tradition relying on naturalism and that all matter is eternal, but it later introduced the concept of a non-creator God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausk_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-klausk-225">[197]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_yoga" title="Raja yoga">Yoga</a> school of Hinduism accepted the concept of a "personal god" and left it to the Hindu to define his or her god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[198]</a></sup> Advaita Vedanta taught a monistic, abstract Self and Oneness in everything, with no room for gods or deity, a perspective that Mohanty calls, "spiritual, not religious".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[199]</a></sup> Bhakti sub-schools of Vedanta taught a creator God that is distinct from each human being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-192">[168]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Graham_Schweig" title="Graham Schweig">Graham Schweig</a>, Hinduism has the strongest presence of the divine feminine in world religion from ancient times to the present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441-228">[200]</a></sup> The goddess is viewed as the heart of the most esoteric Saiva traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[201]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Authority">Authority</span></h3>
<p>Authority and eternal truths play an important role in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> Religious traditions and truths are believed to be contained in its sacred texts, which are accessed and taught by sages, <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">gurus</a>, saints or <a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-1"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> But there is also a strong tradition of the questioning of authority, internal debate and challenging of religious texts in Hinduism. The Hindus believe that this deepens the understanding of the eternal truths and further develops the tradition. Authority "was mediated through [...] an intellectual culture that tended to develop ideas collaboratively, and according to the shared logic of natural reason."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-2"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> Narratives in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> present characters questioning persons of authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-3"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kena_Upanishad" title="Kena Upanishad">Kena Upanishad</a> repeatedly asks <i>kena</i>, 'by what' power something is the case.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-4"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Katha_Upanishad" title="Katha Upanishad">Katha Upanishad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> present narratives where the student criticizes the teacher's inferior answers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-5"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Shiva_Purana" title="Shiva Purana">Shiva Purana</a>, Shiva questions Vishnu and Brahma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-6"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> Doubt plays a repeated role in the <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-7"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jayadeva" title="Jayadeva">Jayadeva's</a> <a href="/wiki/Gita_Govinda" title="Gita Govinda">Gita Govinda</a> presents criticism via the character of <a href="/wiki/Radha" title="Radha">Radha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_230-8"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-230">[202]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Main_traditions">Main traditions</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="594" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/220px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/330px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/440px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A Ganesha-centric <a href="/wiki/Panchayatana_puja" title="Panchayatana puja">Panchayatana</a> ("five deities", from the Smarta tradition): <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> (centre) with <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> (top left), <a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a> (top right), <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> (bottom left) and Surya (bottom right). All these deities also have separate sects dedicated to them.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Hinduism has no central doctrinal authority and many practising Hindus do not claim to belong to any particular denomination or tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[203]</a></sup> Four major denominations are, however, used in scholarly studies: <i>Vaishnavism</i>, <i>Shaivism</i>, <i>Shaktism</i> and <i>Smartism</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-232">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113.2C_134.2C_155-161.2C_167-168_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113.2C_134.2C_155-161.2C_167-168-233">[205]</a></sup> These denominations differ primarily in the central deity worshipped, the traditions and the <a href="/wiki/Soteriology" title="Soteriology">soteriological</a> outlook.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-234">[206]</a></sup> The denominations of Hinduism, states Lipner, are unlike those found in major religions of the world, because Hindu denominations are fuzzy with individuals practicing more than one, and he suggests the term "Hindu polycentrism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[207]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> is the devotional religious tradition that worships <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[208]</a></sup> and his avatars, particularly <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[209]</a></sup> The adherents of this sect are generally non-ascetic, monastic, oriented towards community events and devotionalism practices inspired by "intimate loving, joyous, playful" <i>Krishna</i> and other Vishnu avatars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-234">[206]</a></sup> These practices sometimes include community dancing, singing of <a href="/wiki/Kirtan" title="Kirtan">Kirtans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajans</a>, with sound and music believed by some to have meditative and spiritual powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edwinb_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-edwinb-238">[210]</a></sup> Temple worship and festivals are typically elaborate in Vaishnavism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[211]</a></sup> The Bhagavad Gita and the Ramayana, along with Vishnu-oriented Puranas provide its theistic foundations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[212]</a></sup> Philosophically, their beliefs are rooted in the dualism sub-schools of Vedantic Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[214]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> is the tradition that focuses on <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>. Shaivas are more attracted to ascetic individualism, and it has several sub-schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_234-2"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-234">[206]</a></sup> Their practices include Bhakti-style devotionalism, yet their beliefs lean towards nondual, monistic schools of Hinduism such as Advaita and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_yoga" title="Raja yoga">Yoga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-232">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-edwinb_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-edwinb-238">[210]</a></sup> Some Shaivas worship in temples, while others emphasize yoga, striving to be one with Shiva within.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[215]</a></sup> Avatars are uncommon, and some Shaivas visualize god as half male, half female, as a fusion of the male and female principles (<a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a>). Shaivism is related to Shaktism, wherein Shakti is seen as spouse of Shiva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_232-2"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-232">[204]</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, and participation, with Vaishnavas, in pilgrimages such as the <a href="/wiki/Kumbh_Mela" title="Kumbh Mela">Kumbh Mela</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[216]</a></sup> Shaivism has been more commonly practiced in the Himalayan north from Kashmir to Nepal, and in south India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[217]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> focuses on goddess worship of <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a> or Devi as cosmic mother,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_234-3"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-234">[206]</a></sup> and it is particularly common in northeastern and eastern states of India such as <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">Bengal</a>. Devi is depicted as in gentler forms like <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a>, the consort of Shiva; or, as fierce warrior goddesses like <a href="/wiki/Kali" title="Kali">Kali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga">Durga</a>. Followers of Shaktism recognize <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a> as the power that underlies the male principle. Shaktism is also associated with <a href="/wiki/Tantra" title="Tantra">Tantra</a> practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[218]</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, some of which include processions and idol immersion into sea or other water bodies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[219]</a></sup></p>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smartism" title="Smartism">Smartism</a> centers its worship simultaneously on all the major Hindu deities: Shiva, Vishnu, Shakti, <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kartikeya" title="Kartikeya">Skanda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113-248">[220]</a></sup> The Smarta tradition developed during the (early) Classical Period of Hinduism around the beginning of the Common Era, when Hinduism emerged from the interaction between Brahmanism and local traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996-250">[222]</a></sup> The Smarta tradition is aligned with <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, and regards <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a> as its founder or reformer, who considered worship of God-with-attributes (saguna Brahman) as a journey towards ultimately realizing God-without-attributes (nirguna Brahman, Atman, Self-knowledge).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-williamw_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-williamw-251">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[224]</a></sup> The term <i>Smartism</i> is derived from Smriti texts of Hinduism, meaning those who remember the traditions in the texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_232-3"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-232">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-williamsonp89_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-williamsonp89-253">[225]</a></sup> This Hindu sect practices a philosophical <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">Jnana yoga</a>, scriptural studies, reflection, meditative path seeking an understanding of Self's oneness with God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_232-4"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-232">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[226]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scriptures">Scriptures</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1125" data-file-width="1161" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/220px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/330px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/440px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> is the first and most important Veda<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[227]</a></sup> and is one of the oldest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_texts" title="Religious texts">religious texts</a>. This Rigveda <a href="/wiki/Manuscript" title="Manuscript">manuscript</a> is in <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shruti" title="Shruti">Shruti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smriti</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_scriptures" title="List of Hindu scriptures">List of Hindu scriptures</a></div>
<p>The ancient scriptures of Hinduism are in Sanskrit. These texts are classified into two: Shruti and Smriti. Hindu scriptures were composed, memorized and transmitted verbally, across generations, for many centuries before they were written down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[229]</a></sup> Over many centuries, sages refined the teachings and expanded the Shruti and Smriti, as well as developed Shastras with epistemological and metaphysical theories of six classical schools of Hinduism.</p>
<p><i>Shruti</i> (lit. that which is heard)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart200468_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart200468-258">[230]</a></sup> primarily refers to the <i>Vedas</i>, which form the earliest record of the Hindu scriptures, and are regarded as eternal truths revealed to the ancient sages (<i><a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishis</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20084_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20084-259">[231]</a></sup> There are four <i>Vedas</i> - <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Samaveda" title="Samaveda">Samaveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Yajurveda" title="Yajurveda">Yajurveda</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Atharvaveda" title="Atharvaveda">Atharvaveda</a></i>. Each Veda has been subclassified into four major text types – the <a href="/wiki/Samhita" title="Samhita">Samhitas</a> (mantras and benedictions), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aranyakas" title="Aranyakas">Aranyakas</a> (text on rituals, ceremonies, sacrifices and symbolic-sacrifices), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmanas" title="Brahmanas">Brahmanas</a> (commentaries on rituals, ceremonies and sacrifices), and the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> (text discussing meditation, philosophy and spiritual knowledge).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gflood_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-gflood-260">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[234]</a></sup> The first two parts of the Vedas were subsequently called the <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Karmakāṇḍa</span></i> (ritualistic portion), while the last two form the <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Jñānakāṇḍa</span></i> (knowledge portion, discussing spiritual insight and philosophical teachings).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[238]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Upanishads are the foundation of Hindu philosophical thought, and have profoundly influenced diverse traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-267">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[240]</a></sup> Of the Shrutis (Vedic corpus), they alone are widely influential among Hindus, considered scriptures par excellence of Hinduism, and their central ideas have continued to influence its thoughts and traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_267-1"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-267">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[241]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan</a> states that the Upanishads have played a dominating role ever since their appearance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[242]</a></sup> There are 108 <a href="/wiki/Muktik%C4%81" title="Muktikā">Muktikā</a> Upanishads in Hinduism, of which between 10 and 13 are variously counted by scholars as <a href="/wiki/Mukhya_Upanishads" title="Mukhya Upanishads">Principal Upanishads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[244]</a></sup></p>
<p>The most notable of the Smritis ("remembered") are the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hindu_epics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hindu epics (page does not exist)">Hindu epics</a> and the <i>Puranas</i>. The epics consist of the <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> is an integral part of the <i>Mahabharata</i> and one of the most popular sacred texts of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[245]</a></sup> It is sometimes called <i>Gitopanishad</i>, then placed in the Shruti ("heard") category, being Upanishadic in content.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[246]</a></sup> The <i>Puranas</i>, which started to be composed from c. 300 CE onward,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655-275">[247]</a></sup> contain extensive mythologies, and are central in the distribution of common themes of Hinduism through vivid narratives. The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a></i> is a classical text for the Hindu Yoga tradition, which gained a renewed popularity in the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[248]</a></sup></p>
<p>Since the 19th century Indian modernists have re-asserted the 'Aryan origins' of Hinduism, "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-81">[68]</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Hindu modernists like Vivekananda see the Vedas as the laws of the spiritual world, which would still exist even if they were not revealed to the sages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[250]</a></sup> In Tantric tradition, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Agamas</a></i> refer to authoritative scriptures or the teachings of Shiva to Shakti,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613-279">[251]</a></sup> while <i>Nigamas</i> refers to the Vedas and the teachings of Shakti to Shiva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613_279-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613-279">[251]</a></sup> In Agamic schools of Hinduism, the Vedic literature and the Agamas are equally authoritative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[253]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Practices">Practices</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rituals">Rituals</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">Yajna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2304" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/200px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/300px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/400px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A wedding is the most extensive personal ritual an adult Hindu undertakes in his or her life. A typical <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a> is solemnized before Vedic <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">fire</a> ritual (shown).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[254]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Most Hindus observe religious rituals at home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[255]</a></sup> The rituals vary greatly among regions, villages, and individuals. They are not mandatory in Hinduism. The nature and place of rituals is an individual's choice. Some devout Hindus perform daily rituals such as worshiping at dawn after bathing (usually at a family shrine, and typically includes lighting a lamp and offering foodstuffs before the images of deities), recitation from religious scripts, singing <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">devotional hymns</a>, yoga, <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a>, chanting mantras and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-locceremonies_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-locceremonies-284">[256]</a></sup></p>
<p>Vedic rituals of fire-oblation (<i><a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a></i>) and chanting of Vedic hymns are observed on special occasions, such as a Hindu wedding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[257]</a></sup> Other major life-stage events, such as rituals after death, include the <i>yajña</i> and chanting of Vedic <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[web 5]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Life-cycle_rites_of_passage">Life-cycle rites of passage</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" title="Saṃskāra">Saṃskāra</a></div>
<p>Major life stage milestones are celebrated as <i>sanskara</i> (<i>saṃskāra</i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rites_of_passage" title="Rites of passage">rites of passage</a>) in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pandey_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-287">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-knipe_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-knipe-288">[259]</a></sup> The rites of passage are not mandatory, and vary in details by gender, community and regionally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-289">[260]</a></sup> Gautama <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dharmasutra" title="Dharmasutra">Dharmasutras</a> composed in about the middle of 1st millennium BCE lists 48 sanskaras,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patrick_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-290">[261]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Kalpa_(Vedanga)" title="Kalpa (Vedanga)">Gryhasutra</a> and other texts composed centuries later list between 12 and 16 sanskaras.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pandey_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-287">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carlolson_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-carlolson-291">[262]</a></sup> The list of sanskaras in Hinduism include both external rituals such as those marking a baby's birth and a baby's name giving ceremony, as well as inner rites of resolutions and ethics such as <a href="/wiki/Compassion#Hinduism" title="Compassion">compassion</a> towards all living beings and positive attitude.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patrick_290-1"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-290">[261]</a></sup></p>
<p>The major traditional rites of passage in Hinduism include<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_289-1"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-289">[260]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garbhadhana" title="Garbhadhana">Garbhadhana</a> (pregnancy), <a href="/wiki/Pumsavana" title="Pumsavana">Pumsavana</a> (rite before the fetus begins moving and kicking in womb), <a href="/wiki/Simantonnayana" title="Simantonnayana">Simantonnayana</a> (parting of pregnant woman's hair, baby shower), <i>Jatakarman</i> (rite celebrating the new born baby), <i>Namakarana</i> (naming the child), <i>Nishkramana</i> (baby's first outing from home into the world), <i>Annaprashana</i> (baby's first feeding of solid food), <i>Chudakarana</i> (baby's first haircut, tonsure), <i>Karnavedha</i> (ear piercing), <i>Vidyarambha</i> (baby's start with knowledge), <a href="/wiki/Upanayana" title="Upanayana">Upanayana</a> (entry into a school rite),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[264]</a></sup> <i>Keshanta</i> and <i>Ritusuddhi</i> (first shave for boys, menarche for girls), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samavartana" title="Samavartana">Samavartana</a> (graduation ceremony), Vivaha (wedding), <i>Vratas</i> (fasting, spiritual studies) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antyeshti" title="Antyeshti">Antyeshti</a> (cremation for an adult, burial for a child).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[265]</a></sup> In contemporary times, there is regional variation among Hindus as to which of these <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" title="Saṃskāra">sanskaras</a> are observed; in some cases, additional regional rites of passage such as <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha" title="Śrāddha">Śrāddha</a></i> (ritual of feeding people after cremation) are practiced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_289-2"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-289">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loclifecycle_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-loclifecycle-295">[web 6]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Bhakti_(worship)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bhakti_.28worship.29">Bhakti (worship)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">Japa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">Mantra</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:320px;max-width:320px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vishu-kani_1.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/200px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/300px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/400px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:114px;max-width:114px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/112px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/168px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/224px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 2x" width="112"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">A home shrine with offerings at a regional <a href="/wiki/Vishu" title="Vishu">Vishu</a> festival (left); a priest in a temple (right).</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><i>Bhakti</i> refers to devotion, participation in and the love of a personal god or a representational god by a devotee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclopediabrit_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-encyclopediabrit-296">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karen_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-karen-297">[267]</a></sup> <i>Bhakti marga</i> is considered in Hinduism as one of many possible paths of spirituality and alternate means to moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[268]</a></sup> The other paths, left to the choice of a Hindu, are <i>Jnana marga</i> (path of knowledge), <i>Karma marga</i> (path of works), <i>Rāja marga</i> (path of contemplation and meditation).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-johnmartin_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-johnmartin-299">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[270]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bhakti is practiced in a number of ways, ranging from reciting <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">japas</a> (incantations), to individual private prayers within one's home or in a temple or near a river bank, sometimes in the presence of an idol or image of a deity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199741-50_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199741-50-302">[272]</a></sup> Bhakti is sometimes practiced as a community, such as a <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aarti" title="Aarti">Aarti</a>, musical <a href="/wiki/Kirtan" title="Kirtan">Kirtan</a> or singing <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajan</a>, where devotional verses and hymns are read or poems are sung by a group of devotees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[274]</a></sup> While the choice of the deity is at the discretion of the Hindu, the most observed traditions of Hindu devotionalism include <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva) and <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Shakti).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[275]</a></sup> A Hindu may worship multiple deities, all as henotheistic manifestations of the same ultimate reality, cosmic spirit and absolute spiritual concept called <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a> in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avatars_207-1"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-207">[note 18]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bhakti marga, states Pechelis, is more than ritual devotionalism, it includes practices and spiritual activities aimed at refining one's state of mind, knowing god, participating in god, and internalizing god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gale_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gale-309">[279]</a></sup> While Bhakti practices are popular and easily observable aspect of Hinduism, not all Hindus practice Bhakti, or believe in god-with-attributes (<i>saguna Brahman</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[281]</a></sup> Concurrent Hindu practices include a belief in god-without-attributes, and god within oneself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[283]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_festivals" title="Hindu festivals">Hindu festivals</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="416" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg/300px-Deepawali-festival.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg 1.5x" width="300"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The festival of lights- <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, is celebrated by Hindus all over the world.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Hindu festivals (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <i>Utsava</i>; literally: "to lift higher") are ceremonies that weave individual and social life to dharma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-314">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yustf_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-315">[285]</a></sup> Hinduism has many festivals throughout the year, where the dates are set by the lunisolar <a href="/wiki/Hindu_calendar" title="Hindu calendar">Hindu calendar</a>, many coinciding with either the full moon (<i>Holi</i>) or the new moon (<i>Diwali</i>), often with seasonal changes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-denisecushf_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-316">[286]</a></sup> Some festivals are found only regionally and they celebrate local traditions, while a few such as <i>Holi</i> and <i>Diwali</i> are pan-Hindu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-denisecushf_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-316">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[287]</a></sup></p>
<p>The festivals typically celebrate events from Hinduism, connoting spiritual themes and celebrating aspects of human relationships such as the Sister-Brother bond over the <i>Raksha Bandhan</i> (or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhau-beej" title="Bhau-beej">Bhai Dooj</a>) festival.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yustf_315-1"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-315">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[288]</a></sup> The same festival sometimes marks different stories depending on the Hindu denomination, and the celebrations incorporate regional themes, traditional agriculture, local arts, family get togethers, <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja</a> rituals and feasts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_314-1"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-314">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[289]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some major regional or pan-Hindu festivals include:</p>
<div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-4" style="-moz-column-count: 4; -webkit-column-count: 4; column-count: 4;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Makar_Sankranti" title="Makar Sankranti">Makar Sankranti</a></li>

</ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites_in_India" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites in India">Tirtha locations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yatra" title="Yatra">Yatra</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kedarnathroute.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="653" data-file-width="1001" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Kedarnathroute.jpg/200px-Kedarnathroute.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Kedarnathroute.jpg/300px-Kedarnathroute.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Kedarnathroute.jpg/400px-Kedarnathroute.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kedarnathroute.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Pilgrimage to <a href="/wiki/Kedarnath" title="Kedarnath">Kedarnath</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Pilgrimage sites are called <i><a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha</a></i>, <i>Kshetra</i>, <i>Gopitha</i> or <i>Mahalaya</i> in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJames_G._Lochtefeld2002698-699_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJames_G._Lochtefeld2002698-699-320">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen20134.2C_22.2C_27.2C_140-148.2C_157-158_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen20134.2C_22.2C_27.2C_140-148.2C_157-158-321">[291]</a></sup> The process or journey associated with <i>Tirtha</i> is called <i>Tirtha-yatra</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832-322">[292]</a></sup> According to the Hindu text <i><a href="/wiki/Skanda_Purana" title="Skanda Purana">Skanda Purana</a></i>, Tirtha are of three kinds: Jangam Tirtha is to a place movable of a <a href="/wiki/Sadhu" title="Sadhu">sadhu</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishi</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">guru</a>; Sthawar Tirtha is to a place immovable, like Benaras, Hardwar, Mount Kailash, holy rivers; while Manas Tirtha is to a place of mind of truth, charity, patience, compassion, soft speech, soul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sharmasinha_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-sharmasinha-323">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[294]</a></sup> <i>Tīrtha-yatra</i> is, states Knut A. Jacobsen, anything that has a salvific value to a Hindu, and includes pilgrimage sites such as mountains or forests or seashore or rivers or ponds, as well as virtues, actions, studies or state of mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen2013157-158_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen2013157-158-325">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAxel_MichaelsBarbara_Harshav_.28Transl.292004288-289_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAxel_MichaelsBarbara_Harshav_.28Transl.292004288-289-326">[296]</a></sup></p>
<p>Pilgrimage sites of Hinduism are mentioned in the epic Mahabharata and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953561_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953561-327">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127-9_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127-9-328">[298]</a></sup> Most Puranas include large sections on <i>Tirtha Mahatmya</i> along with tourist guides,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[299]</a></sup> which describe sacred sites and places to visit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953559-560_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953559-560-330">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[302]</a></sup> In these texts, Varanasi (Benares, Kashi), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rameshwaram" title="Rameshwaram">Rameshwaram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanchipuram" title="Kanchipuram">Kanchipuram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dwarka" title="Dwarka">Dwarka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puri" title="Puri">Puri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haridwar" title="Haridwar">Haridwar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sri_Rangam" title="Sri Rangam">Sri Rangam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vrindavan" title="Vrindavan">Vrindavan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ayodhya" title="Ayodhya">Ayodhya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tirupati" title="Tirupati">Tirupati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mayapur" title="Mayapur">Mayapur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathdwara" title="Nathdwara">Nathdwara</a>, twelve <a href="/wiki/Jyotirlinga" title="Jyotirlinga">Jyotirlinga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shakti_Peetha" title="Shakti Peetha">Shakti Peetha</a> have been mentioned as particularly holy sites, along with geographies where major rivers meet (<i>sangam</i>) or join the sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953553-556.2C_560-561_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953553-556.2C_560-561-333">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127-9_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127-9-328">[298]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kumbhamela" title="Kumbhamela">Kumbhamela</a>, which rotates at a gap of three years, between Prayaga (renamed to Allahabad in the late medieval era), Hardwar, Ujjain and Nasik, is popular with tens of millions of Hindu pilgrims participating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlaus_K._Klostermaier2010553_note_55_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlaus_K._Klostermaier2010553_note_55-334">[304]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some pilgrimage are a part of a <i>Vrata</i> (vow), which a Hindu may make for a number of reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-11_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-11-335">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836-336">[306]</a></sup> It may mark a special occasion, such as the birth of a baby, or as part of a <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> such as a baby's first haircut, or after healing from a sickness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-337">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[308]</a></sup> It may, states Eck, also be the result of prayers answered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_337-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-337">[307]</a></sup> An alternate reason for Tirtha, for some Hindus, is to respect wishes or in memory of a beloved person after his or her death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_337-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-337">[307]</a></sup> This may include dispersing their cremation ashes in a Tirtha region in a forest, mountain, river or sea to honor the wishes of the dead. The journey to a Tirtha, assert some Hindu texts, helps one overcome the sorrow of the loss.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_337-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-337">[307]</a></sup></p>
<p>Other reasons for a Tirtha in Hinduism is to rejuvenate or gain spiritual merit by traveling to famed temples or bathe in rivers such as the Ganges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833-5_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833-5-339">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-holmbowker69_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-holmbowker69-341">[311]</a></sup> Tirtha has been one of the recommended means of addressing remorse and to perform penance, for unintentional errors and intentional sins, in the Hindu tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobert_Lingat197398-99_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobert_Lingat197398-99-342">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834-343">[313]</a></sup> The proper procedure for a pilgrimage is widely discussed in Hindu texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953573_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953573-344">[314]</a></sup> The most accepted view is that the greatest austerity comes from traveling on foot, or part of the journey is on foot, and that the use of a conveyance is only acceptable if the pilgrimage is otherwise impossible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953576.E2.80.93577_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953576.E2.80.93577-345">[315]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</a> is not mandatory in Hinduism, though many adherents undertake them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004-346">[316]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2017)">page needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Person_and_society">Person and society</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Varnas">Varnas</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">Varna (Hinduism)</a></div>
<p>Hindu society has been categorised into four classes, called <i>varnas</i>. They are the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a></i>: Vedic teachers and priests; the <i><a href="/wiki/Kshatriya" title="Kshatriya">Kshatriyas</a></i>: warriors and kings; the <i><a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishyas</a></i>: farmers and merchants; and the <i><a href="/wiki/Shudra" title="Shudra">Shudras</a></i>: servants and labourers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[317]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gītā</a></i> links the <i>varna</i> to an individual's duty (<i>svadharma</i>), inborn nature (<i>svabhāva</i>), and natural tendencies (<i><a href="/wiki/Gu%E1%B9%87a" title="Guṇa">guṇa</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264-348">[318]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Manusmriti" title="Manusmriti">Manusmṛiti</a></i> categorises the different castes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[web 7]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some mobility and flexibility within the varnas challenge allegations of social discrimination in the caste system, as has been pointed out by several sociologists,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Silverberg_Paper_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-Silverberg_Paper-350">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[320]</a></sup> although some other scholars disagree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[321]</a></sup> Scholars debate whether the so-called <i><a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste system</a></i> is part of Hinduism sanctioned by the scriptures or social custom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[web 8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[note 19]</a></sup> And various contemporary scholars have argued that the caste system was constructed by the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British colonial regime</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[323]</a></sup></p>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">renunciant</a> man of knowledge is usually called <i>Varnatita</i> or "beyond all varnas" in Vedantic works. The bhiksu is advised to not bother about the caste of the family from which he begs his food. Scholars like Adi Sankara affirm that not only is Brahman beyond all varnas, the man who is identified with Him also transcends the distinctions and limitations of caste.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[324]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Yoga">Yoga</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="822" data-file-width="832" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/200px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/300px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/400px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A statue of <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> in yogic meditation.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a></div>
<p>In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life, there are several methods (yogas) that sages have taught for reaching that goal. Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body, mind and consciousness for health, tranquility and spiritual insight. This is done through a system of postures and exercises to practise control of the body and mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[325]</a></sup> Texts dedicated to Yoga include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hatha_Yoga_Pradipika" title="Hatha Yoga Pradipika">Hatha Yoga Pradipika</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> and, as their philosophical and historical basis, the Upanishads. Yoga is means, and the four major <i>marga</i> (paths) discussed in Hinduism are: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhakti_Yoga" title="Bhakti Yoga">Bhakti Yoga</a> (the path of love and devotion), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karma_Yoga" title="Karma Yoga">Karma Yoga</a> (the path of right action), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R%C4%81ja_Yoga" title="Rāja Yoga">Rāja Yoga</a> (the path of meditation), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J%C3%B1%C4%81na_Yoga" title="Jñāna Yoga">Jñāna Yoga</a> (the path of wisdom)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaressentgeneral_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaressentgeneral-360">[326]</a></sup> An individual may prefer one or some yogas over others, according to his or her inclination and understanding. Practice of one yoga does not exclude others.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbolism">Symbolism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha-aum.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1808" data-file-width="1684" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/200px-Ganesha-aum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/300px-Ganesha-aum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/400px-Ganesha-aum.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha-aum.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The Hindu deity <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> is sometimes linked to the symbol <i><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[327]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Hinduism has a developed system of symbolism and iconography to represent the sacred in art, architecture, literature and worship. These symbols gain their meaning from the scriptures or cultural traditions. The syllable <i><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a></i> (which represents the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a></i> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" title="Atman (Hinduism)">Atman</a>) has grown to represent Hinduism itself, while other markings such as the <a href="/wiki/Swastika#Hinduism" title="Swastika">Swastika</a> sign represent auspiciousness,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041-362">[328]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Tilaka" title="Tilaka">Tilaka</a></i> (literally, seed) on forehead – considered to be the location of spiritual third eye,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[329]</a></sup> marks ceremonious welcome, blessing or one's participation in a ritual or rite of passage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[330]</a></sup> Elaborate <i>Tilaka</i> with lines may also identify a devotee of a particular denomination. Flowers, birds, animals, instruments, symmetric <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandala</a> drawings, objects, idols are all part of symbolic iconography in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[332]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Ahimsa,_vegetarianism_and_other_food_customs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ahimsa.2C_vegetarianism_and_other_food_customs">Ahimsa, vegetarianism and other food customs</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">Ahimsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diet_in_Hinduism" title="Diet in Hinduism">Diet in Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sattvic_diet" title="Sattvic diet">Sattvic diet</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a></div>
<p>Hindus advocate the practice of <span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">ahiṃsā</span> (non-violence) and respect for all life because divinity is believed to permeate all beings, including plants and non-human animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[333]</a></sup> The term <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">ahiṃsā</span></i> appears in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radhakrishnan_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-Radhakrishnan-368">[334]</a></sup> the epic <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[335]</a></sup> and <span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">ahiṃsā</span> is the first of the five <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (vows of self-restraint) in <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Patanjali's Yoga Sutras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[336]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gosala_in_Guntur,_India.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/200px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/300px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/400px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gosala_in_Guntur,_India.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A <i>goshala</i> or cow shelter at <a href="/wiki/Guntur" title="Guntur">Guntur</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In accordance with <span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">ahiṃsā</span>, many Hindus embrace vegetarianism to respect higher forms of life. Estimates of strict <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarian" title="Lacto vegetarian">lacto vegetarians</a> in India (includes adherents of all religions) who never eat any meat, fish or eggs vary between 20% and 42%, while others are either less strict vegetarians or non-vegetarians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veg_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-veg-371">[337]</a></sup> Those who eat meat seek <a href="/wiki/Jhatka" title="Jhatka">Jhatka</a> (quick death) method of meat production, and dislike <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">Halal</a> (slow bled death) method, believing that quick death method reduces suffering to the animal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[339]</a></sup> The food habits vary with region, with Bengali Hindus and Hindus living in Himalayan regions, or river delta regions, regularly eating meat and fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[340]</a></sup> Some avoid meat on specific festivals or occasions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[341]</a></sup> Observant Hindus who do eat meat almost always abstain from beef. The cow in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker and a maternal figure,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[342]</a></sup> and Hindu society honours the cow as a symbol of unselfish giving.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[343]</a></sup></p>
<p>There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by a strict <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian">vegetarian</a> diet in modern times. Some adhere to a diet that is devoid of meat, eggs, and seafood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[344]</a></sup> Food affects body, mind and spirit in Hindu beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vasudha_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vasudha-379">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rosen_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rosen-380">[346]</a></sup> Hindu texts such as Śāṇḍilya Upanishad<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176-381">[347]</a></sup> and Svātmārāma<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-svatmaram_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-svatmaram-382">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[349]</a></sup> recommend <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a> (eating in moderation) as one of the <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (virtuous self restraints). The Bhagavad Gita links body and mind to food one consumes in verses 17.8 through 17.10.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ckc_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-ckc-384">[350]</a></sup></p>
<p>Some Hindus such as those belonging to the Shaktism tradition,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[351]</a></sup> and Hindus in regions such as Bali and Nepal<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483.2C_Chapter_4_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483.2C_Chapter_4-386">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[353]</a></sup> practise <a href="/wiki/Animal_sacrifice_in_Hinduism" title="Animal sacrifice in Hinduism">animal sacrifice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483.2C_Chapter_4_386-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483.2C_Chapter_4-386">[352]</a></sup> The sacrificed animal is eaten as ritual food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[354]</a></sup> In contrast, the Vaishnava Hindus abhor and vigorously oppose animal sacrifice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101-102.2C_Quote:_.22Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point.2C_.28.2C.2C.2C.29_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism.27s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._.28....29_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation.2C_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism.2C_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes.22._390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101-102.2C_Quote:_.22Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point.2C_.28.2C.2C.2C.29_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism.27s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._.28....29_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation.2C_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism.2C_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes.22.-390">[356]</a></sup> The principle of non-violence to animals has been so thoroughly adopted in Hinduism that animal sacrifice is uncommon<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[357]</a></sup> and historically reduced to a vestigial marginal practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[358]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p>According to a study by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Centre" title="Pew Research Centre">Pew Research Centre</a>, Hindus are among the religious groups having least years of formal education. It further claims that they are among the fastest improving communities too.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[359]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Institutions">Institutions</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Temple">Temple</span></h3>
<table class="infobox" style="width:22em">

<div style="padding:1px"></div>
