</tr>
</table>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">Murti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">Hindu iconography</a></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a> is a house of god(s).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[360]</a></sup> It is a space and structure designed to bring human beings and gods together, infused with symbolism to express the ideas and beliefs of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-395">[361]</a></sup> A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology, the highest spire or dome representing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Meru" title="Mount Meru">Mount Meru</a> – reminder of the abode of Brahma and the center of spiritual universe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[362]</a></sup> the carvings and iconography symbolically presenting <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">kama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[364]</a></sup> The layout, the motifs, the plan and the building process recite ancient rituals, geometric symbolisms, and reflect beliefs and values innate within various schools of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-395">[361]</a></sup> Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for many Hindus (not all), as well as landmarks for arts, annual festivals, <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> rituals, and community celebrations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[366]</a></sup></p>
<p>Hindu temples come in many styles, diverse locations, deploy different construction methods and are adapted to different deities and regional beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[367]</a></sup> Two major styles of Hindu temples include the <a href="/wiki/Gopuram" title="Gopuram">Gopuram</a> style found in south India, and <a href="/wiki/Nagara" title="Nagara">Nagara</a> style found in north India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[369]</a></sup> Other styles include cave, forest and mountain temples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[370]</a></sup> Yet, despite their differences, almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural principles, core ideas, symbolism and themes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_395-2"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-395">[361]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many temples feature one or more idols (<a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">murtis</a>). The idol and Grabhgriya in the Brahma-pada (the center of the temple), under the main spire, serves as a focal point (<i>darsana</i>, a sight) in a Hindu temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[371]</a></sup> In larger temples, the central space typically is surrounded by an ambulatory for the devotee to walk around and ritually circumambulate the <a href="/wiki/Purusha" title="Purusha">Purusa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>), the universal essence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_395-3"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-395">[361]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ashrama">Ashrama</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ashrama_(stage)" title="Ashrama (stage)">Ashrama (stage)</a></div>
<p>Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas (phases or life stages; another meaning includes monastery).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[372]</a></sup> The four ashramas are: <a href="/wiki/Brahmacharya" title="Brahmacharya">Brahmacharya</a> (student), <a href="/wiki/Grihastha" title="Grihastha">Grihastha</a> (householder), <a href="/wiki/Vanaprastha" title="Vanaprastha">Vanaprastha</a> (retired) and <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (renunciation).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rks_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-rks-407">[373]</a></sup></p>
<p>Brahmacharya represents the bachelor student stage of life. Grihastha refers to the individual's married life, with the duties of maintaining a household, raising a family, educating one's children, and leading a family-centred and a dharmic social life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rks_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-rks-407">[373]</a></sup> Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding, and has been considered as the most important of all stages in sociological context, as Hindus in this stage not only pursued a virtuous life, they produced food and wealth that sustained people in other stages of life, as well as the offsprings that continued mankind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aw0_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-aw0-408">[374]</a></sup> Vanaprastha is the retirement stage, where a person hands over household responsibilities to the next generation, took an advisory role, and gradually withdrew from the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alnu_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-alnu-409">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[376]</a></sup> The Sannyasa stage marks renunciation and a state of disinterest and detachment from material life, generally without any meaningful property or home (ascetic state), and focused on Moksha, peace and simple spiritual life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-412">[378]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Ashramas system has been one facet of the Dharma concept in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aw2_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-aw2-413">[379]</a></sup> Combined with four proper goals of human life (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purusartha" title="Purusartha">Purusartha</a>), the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at providing a Hindu with fulfilling life and spiritual liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aw0_408-1"><a href="#cite_note-aw0-408">[374]</a></sup> While these stages are typically sequential, any person can enter Sannyasa (ascetic) stage and become an Ascetic at any time after the Brahmacharya stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[380]</a></sup> Sannyasa is not religiously mandatory in Hinduism, and elderly people are free to live with their families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[381]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monasticism">Monasticism</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="461" data-file-width="691" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/200px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/300px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/400px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A sadhu in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a>, India.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Some Hindus choose to live a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monastic" title="Monastic">monastic</a> life (Sannyāsa) in pursuit of liberation (moksha) or another form of spiritual perfection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ellinger70_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-25">[19]</a></sup> Monastics commit themselves to a simple and celibate life, detached from material pursuits, of meditation and spiritual contemplation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential112_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential112-416">[382]</a></sup> A Hindu monk is called a <i><a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sanyāsī</a></i>, <i>Sādhu</i>, or <i>Swāmi</i>. A female renunciate is called a <i>Sanyāsini</i>. Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>-driven lifestyle and dedication to spiritual liberation (moksha) – believed to be the ultimate goal of life in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_412-1"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-412">[378]</a></sup> Some monastics live in monasteries, while others wander from place to place, depending on donated food and charity for their needs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[383]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Periodisation">Periodisation</span></h3>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks plainlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">

<th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em;padding-bottom:0.5em; font-size:130%;"><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_South_Asian_history" title="Outline of South Asian history">Outline of South Asian history</a></th>
</tr>
<tr>

<li><a href="/wiki/Linguistic_history_of_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Linguistic history of the Indian subcontinent">Language</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Indian_literature" title="Indian literature">Literature</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Indian_maritime_history" title="Indian maritime history">Maritime</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_India" title="Military history of India">Military</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_studies" title="Pakistan studies">Pakistan studies</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_South_Asia" title="History of science and technology in South Asia">Science &amp; Technology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Indian_history" title="Timeline of Indian history">Timeline</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template:History of South Asia"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template talk:History of South Asia"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_South_Asia&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><a href="/wiki/James_Mill" title="James Mill">James Mill</a> (1773–1836), in his <i><a href="/wiki/The_History_of_British_India" title="The History of British India">The History of British India</a></i> (1817),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii-418">[384]</a></sup> distinguished three phases in the history of India, namely Hindu, Muslim and British civilisations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii_418-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii-418">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMisra2004194_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMisra2004194-419">[385]</a></sup> This periodisation has been criticised for the misconceptions it has given rise to.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[386]</a></sup> Another periodisation is the division into "ancient, classical, mediaeval and modern periods".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199621_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199621-421">[387]</a></sup> An elaborate periodisation may be as follows:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-18">[12]</a></sup></p>
<ul>
<li>Prevedic religions (pre-history and Indus Valley Civilisation; until c. 1500 BCE);</li>
<li>Vedic period (c. 1500–500 BCE);</li>
<li>"Second Urbanisation" (c. 500–200 BCE);</li>
<li>Classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE-1100 CE);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[note 20]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dd>
<ul>
<li>Pre-classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE-300 CE);</li>
<li>"Golden Age" (Gupta Empire) (c. 320–650 CE);</li>
<li>Late-Classical Hinduism - Puranic Hinduism (c. 650–1100 CE);</li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Islam and sects of Hinduism (c. 1200–1700 CE);</li>
<li>Modern Hinduism (from c. 1800).</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h3>
<p>Hinduism is a fusion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard200750_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard200750-429">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-2"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">[note 3]</a></sup> or synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">[note 4]</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fusion_12-2"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">[note 5]</a></sup> Among the roots of Hinduism are the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">historical Vedic religion</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_Age_India" title="Iron Age India">Iron Age India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[394]</a></sup> itself already the product of "a composite of the indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200628_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200628-431">[395]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vedic_composite_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vedic_composite-432">[note 21]</a></sup> but also the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sramana" title="Sramana">Sramana</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomez201342_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomez201342-433">[396]</a></sup> or renouncer traditions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_93-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-93">[78]</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">northeast India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomez201342_433-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomez201342-433">[396]</a></sup> and mesolithic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger201066_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger201066-434">[397]</a></sup> and neolithic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006xvii_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006xvii-435">[398]</a></sup> cultures of India, such as the religions of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[399]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dravidian_peoples" title="Dravidian peoples">Dravidian</a> traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[400]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Adivasi" title="Adivasi">local traditions</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_93-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-93">[78]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tribal_religions_in_India" title="Tribal religions in India">tribal religions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v-438">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[note 22]</a></sup></p>
<p>This "Hindu synthesis" emerged after the Vedic period, between 500<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup>-200<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup> the beginning of the "Epic and Puranic" c.q. "Preclassical" period, <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> and incorporated śramaṇic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200488_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200488-440">[402]</a></sup> and Buddhist influences<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins2010_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins2010-441">[403]</a></sup> and the emerging bhakti tradition into the Brahmanical fold via the Smriti literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-442">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> From northern India this "Hindu synthesis", and its societal divisions, spread to southern India and parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-228.2C_339-353.2C_specifically_p.76-79_and_p.199_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-228.2C_339-353.2C_specifically_p.76-79_and_p.199-443">[405]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Prevedic_religions_(until_c._1500_BCE)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prevedic_religions_.28until_c._1500_BCE.29">Prevedic religions (until c. 1500 BCE)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Pashupati.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="926" data-file-width="920" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/220px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/330px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/440px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Pashupati.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <i><a href="/wiki/Pashupati" title="Pashupati">Pashupati</a></i> seal, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilization" title="Indus Valley civilization">Indus Valley civilization</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The earliest <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_religion" title="Prehistoric religion">prehistoric religion</a> in India that may have left its traces in Hinduism comes from mesolithic as observed in the sites such as the rock paintings of <a href="/wiki/Bhimbetka_rock_shelters" title="Bhimbetka rock shelters">Bhimbetka rock shelters</a> dating to a period of 30,000 BCE or older,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[note 23]</a></sup> as well as neolithic times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[note 24]</a></sup> Some of the religious practices can be considered to have originated in 4000 BCE. Several <a href="/wiki/Tribal_religions_in_India" title="Tribal religions in India">tribal religions</a> still exist, though their practices may not resemble those of prehistoric religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[web 10]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Possehl" title="Gregory Possehl">Possehl</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> "provides a logical, if somewhat arbitrary, starting point for some aspects of the later Hindu tradition".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002154_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002154-447">[406]</a></sup> The religion of this period included worship of a Great male god, which is compared to a proto-Shiva, and probably a Mother Goddess, that may prefigure <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a>. However these links of deities and practices of the Indus religion to later-day Hinduism are subject to both political contention and scholarly dispute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002141.E2.80.93156_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002141.E2.80.93156-448">[407]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Vedic_period_(c._1500–500_BCE)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_period_.28c._1500.E2.80.93500_BCE.29">Vedic period (c. 1500–500 BCE)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins_and_development">Origins and development</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="float:right;margin:0 auto;">
<tr>
<th class="navbox-title">Indo-Aryan migration and Vedic period</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<div class="center">
<div class="thumb tnone">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="450" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/IE_expansion.png/400px-IE_expansion.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5a/IE_expansion.png 1.5x" width="400"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Scheme of <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a> from ca. 4000 to 1000 BCE according to the <a href="/wiki/Kurgan_hypothesis" title="Kurgan hypothesis">Kurgan hypothesis</a>. The magenta area corresponds to the assumed <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_Urheimat_hypotheses" title="Proto-Indo-European Urheimat hypotheses">Urheimat</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Samara_culture" title="Samara culture">Samara culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sredny_Stog_culture" title="Sredny Stog culture">Sredny Stog culture</a>). The red area corresponds to the area which may have been settled by Indo-European-speaking peoples up to c. 2500 BCE; the orange area to 1000 BCE. (Christopher I. Beckwith (2009), <i>Empires of the Silk Road</i>, Oxford University Press, p.30)</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="center">
<div class="thumb tnone">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Andronovo_culture.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="450" height="311" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Andronovo_culture.png/400px-Andronovo_culture.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0c/Andronovo_culture.png 1.5x" width="400"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Andronovo_culture.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Map of the approximate maximal extent of the Andronovo culture. The formative <a href="/wiki/Sintashta_culture" title="Sintashta culture">Sintashta-Petrovka</a> culture is shown in darker red. The location of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Spoke" title="Spoke">spoke</a>-wheeled <a href="/wiki/Chariot" title="Chariot">chariot</a> finds is indicated in purple. Adjacent and overlapping cultures (<a href="/wiki/Afanasevo_culture" title="Afanasevo culture">Afanasevo culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Srubna_culture" title="Srubna culture">Srubna culture</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMAC" title="BMAC">BMAC</a>) are shown in green.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="center">
<div class="thumb tnone">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indo-Iranian_origins.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="530" data-file-width="581" height="365" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Indo-Iranian_origins.png/400px-Indo-Iranian_origins.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b8/Indo-Iranian_origins.png 1.5x" width="400"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indo-Iranian_origins.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Archaeological cultures associated with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Iranian_migration" title="Indo-Iranian migration">Indo-Iranian migrations</a> (after <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Indo-European_Culture" title="Encyclopedia of Indo-European Culture">EIEC</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Andronovo_culture" title="Andronovo culture">Andronovo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMAC" title="BMAC">BMAC</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yaz_culture" title="Yaz culture">Yaz</a> cultures have often been associated with Indo-Iranian migrations. The <a href="/wiki/Gandhara_grave_culture" title="Gandhara grave culture">GGC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemetery_H_culture" title="Cemetery H culture">Cemetery H</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper_Hoard_Culture" title="Copper Hoard Culture">Copper Hoard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture" title="Painted Grey Ware culture">PGW</a> cultures are candidates for cultures associated with Indo-Aryan movements.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="center">
<div class="thumb tnone">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Early_Vedic_Culture_(1700-1100_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="863" data-file-width="1200" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/400px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/600px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/800px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png 2x" width="400"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Early_Vedic_Culture_(1700-1100_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Early Vedic Period.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="center">
<div class="thumb tnone">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="863" data-file-width="1200" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/400px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/600px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/800px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 2x" width="400"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Late Vedic Period.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Aryans" title="Indo-Aryans">Indo-Aryans</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration" title="Indo-Aryan migration">Indo-Aryan migration</a></div>
<p>The Vedic period, named after the Vedic religion of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryans</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008185_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008185-449">[408]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[note 25]</a></sup> lasted from c. 1500 to 500 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432-452">[410]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[note 26]</a></sup> The Indo-Aryans were pastoralists<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-455">[412]</a></sup> who migrated into north-western India after the collapse of the Indus Valley Civilization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35-456">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-457">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[note 27]</a></sup></p>
<p>During the early Vedic period (c. 1500–1100 BCE<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_455-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-455">[412]</a></sup>) Vedic tribes were pastoralists, wandering around in north-west India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-48_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-48-461">[417]</a></sup> After 1100 BCE the Vedic tribes moved into the western Ganges Plain, adapting an agrarical lifestyle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_455-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-455">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-93_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-93-462">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein201048-49_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein201048-49-463">[419]</a></sup> Rudimentary state-forms appeared, of which the <a href="/wiki/Kuru_Kingdom" title="Kuru Kingdom">Kuru</a>-Pañcāla union was the most influential.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel19956_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel19956-464">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201051-53_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201051-53-465">[421]</a></sup> It was a tribal union, which developed into the first recorded <a href="/wiki/State_(polity)" title="State (polity)">state-level society</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a> around 1000 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_455-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-455">[412]</a></sup> This, according to Witzel, decisively changed the Vedic heritage of the early Vedic period, collecting the Vedic hymns into collections, and shifting ritual exchange within a tribe to social exchange within the larger Kuru realm through complicated Srauta rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel199511_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel199511-466">[422]</a></sup> In this period, states Samuel, emerged the Brahmana and Aranyaka layers of Vedic texts, which merged into the earliest Upanishads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201025_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201025-467">[423]</a></sup> These texts began to ask the meaning of a ritual, adding increasing levels of philosophical and metaphysical speculation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201025_467-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201025-467">[423]</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Hinduism#Roots_of_Hinduism" title="Hinduism">"Hindu synthesis"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-10"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_religion">Vedic religion</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Historical Vedic religion</a></div>
<p>The Indo-Aryans brought with them their language<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201053-56_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201053-56-468">[424]</a></sup> and religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199630_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-469">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-7_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-7-470">[426]</a></sup> The Vedic beliefs and practices of the pre-classical era were closely related to the hypothesised <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_religion" title="Proto-Indo-European religion">Proto-Indo-European religion</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Woodard2006_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-Woodard2006-471">[427]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Iranian_religion" title="Proto-Indo-Iranian religion">Indo-Iranian religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beckwith2009p32_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beckwith2009p32-472">[428]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[note 28]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Vedic religion history is unclear and "heavily contested", states Samuel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201026-27.2C_Quote:_.22In_fact_the_whole_question_of_the_early_history_of_the_Indo-Aryan_and_Indo-Iranian_speaking_peoples_is_both_heavily_contested_and.2C_at_least_at_this_point_in_time.2C_largely_undecidable..22_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201026-27.2C_Quote:_.22In_fact_the_whole_question_of_the_early_history_of_the_Indo-Aryan_and_Indo-Iranian_speaking_peoples_is_both_heavily_contested_and.2C_at_least_at_this_point_in_time.2C_largely_undecidable..22-480">[435]</a></sup> In the later Vedic period, it co-existed with local religions, such as the mother goddess worshipping <a href="/wiki/Yaksha" title="Yaksha">Yaksha</a> cults.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasham198974-75_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasham198974-75-481">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[web 11]</a></sup> The Vedic was itself likely the product of "a composite of the indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200628_431-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200628-431">[395]</a></sup> David Gordon White cites three other mainstream scholars who "have emphatically demonstrated" that Vedic religion is partially derived from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilizations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vedic_composite_432-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vedic_composite-432">[note 21]</a></sup> Their religion was further developed when they migrated into the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Ganges Plain</a> after c. 1100 BCE and became settled farmers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_455-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-455">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201048-51.2C_61-93_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201048-51.2C_61-93-485">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20078-10_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20078-10-486">[440]</a></sup> further syncretising with the native cultures of northern India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010-487">[441]</a></sup></p>
<p>The composition of the Vedic literature began in the 2nd millennium BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201027-31_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201027-31-488">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[443]</a></sup> The oldest of these Vedic texts is the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>, composed between c. 1500-1200 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199637_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199637-490">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel19954_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel19954-491">[445]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454-492">[446]</a></sup> though a wider approximation of c. 1700–1100 BCE has also been given.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOberlies1998158_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOberlies1998158-493">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[448]</a></sup></p>
<p>The first half of the 1st millennium BCE was a period of great intellectual and social-cultural ferment in ancient India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[449]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826-41_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826-41-496">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[note 29]</a></sup> New ideas developed both in the Vedic tradition in the form of the Upanishads, and outside of the Vedic tradition through the Śramaṇa movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[454]</a></sup> For example, prior to the birth of the Buddha and the Mahavira, and related Sramana movements, the Brahmanical tradition had questioned the meaning and efficacy of Vedic rituals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[455]</a></sup> then internalized and variously reinterpreted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Srauta" title="Srauta">Vedic fire rituals</a> as ethical concepts such as Truth, Rite, Tranquility or <a href="/wiki/Temperance_(virtue)" title="Temperance (virtue)">Restraint</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129-503">[456]</a></sup> The 9th and 8th centuries BCE witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads with such ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_503-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129-503">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Religions_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-World_Religions-504">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:183</sup> Other ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Principal_Upanishads" title="Principal Upanishads">Principal Upanishads</a> were composed in the centuries that followed, forming the foundation of classical Hinduism and the Vedanta (conclusion of the Veda) literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[458]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id='"Second_Urbanisation"_(c._500–200_BCE)'></span><span class="mw-headline" id=".22Second_Urbanisation.22_.28c._500.E2.80.93200_BCE.29">"Second Urbanisation" (c. 500–200 BCE)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sramana" title="Sramana">Sramana</a></div>
<p>Increasing urbanisation of India between 800 and 400 BCE, and possibly the spread of urban diseases, contributed to the rise of ascetic movements and of new ideas which challenged the orthodox <a href="/wiki/Brahmanism" title="Brahmanism">Brahmanism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199681-82_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199681-82-506">[459]</a></sup> These ideas led to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sramana" title="Sramana">Sramana</a> movements, of which Mahavira (c. 549–477 BCE), proponent of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddha" title="Buddha">Buddha</a> (c. 563-483), founder of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, were the most prominent icons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Religions_504-1"><a href="#cite_note-World_Religions-504">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:184</sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">ascetic</a> tradition of Vedic period in part created the foundational theories of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara" title="Samsara">samsara</a> and of moksha (liberation from samsara), which became characteristic for Hinduism, along with Buddhism and Jainism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[note 30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaju199242_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaju199242-508">[460]</a></sup></p>
<p>These ascetic concepts were adopted by schools of Hinduism as well as other major Indian religions, but key differences between their premises defined their further development. Hinduism, for example, developed its ideas with the premise that every human being has a soul (<i>atman</i>, self), while Buddhism developed with the premise that there is no soul or self.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[462]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[463]</a></sup></p>
<p>The chronology of these religious concepts is unclear, and scholars contest which religion affected the other as well as the chronological sequence of the ancient texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[465]</a></sup> Pratt notes that <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Oldenberg" title="Hermann Oldenberg">Oldenberg</a> (1854–1920), <a href="/wiki/Karl_Eugen_Neumann" title="Karl Eugen Neumann">Neumann</a> (1865–1915) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarvapalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan</a> (1888–1975) believed that the Buddhist canon had been influenced by Upanishads, while <a href="/wiki/Louis_de_La_Vall%C3%A9e-Poussin" title="Louis de La Vallée-Poussin">la Vallee Poussin</a> thinks the influence was nihil, and "Eliot and several others insist that on some points such as the existence of soul or self the Buddha was directly antithetical to the Upanishads".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[note 31]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Classical_Hinduism_(c._200_BCE_–_1100_CE)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_Hinduism_.28c._200_BCE_.E2.80.93_1100_CE.29">Classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE – 1100 CE)</span></h3>
<p>From about 500 BCE through about 300 CE, the Vedic-Brahmanic synthesis or "Hindu synthesis" continued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-11"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup> Classical Hindu and Sramanic (particularly Buddhist) ideas spread within Indian subcontinent, as well outside India such as in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[468]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">parts of Southeast Asia</a> (coasts of Indonesia and peninsular Thailand).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Samuel-northsouth_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-Samuel-northsouth-518">[note 32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[469]</a></sup></p>
<dl>
<dt>Pre-classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE – 300 CE)</dt>
</dl>
<p>The "Hindu synthesis" or "Brahmanical synthesis"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-12"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> incorporated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sramana" title="Sramana">Sramanic</a> and Buddhist influences<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-9"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins2010_441-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins2010-441">[403]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too vague attribution or weasel words. (March 2015)">which?</span></a></i>]</sup> into the "Brahmanical fold" via the Smriti ("remembered") literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_442-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-442">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-10"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">[11]</a></sup> According to Embree, several other religious traditions had existed side by side with the Vedic religion. These indigenous religions "eventually found a place under the broad mantle of the Vedic religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988277_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988277-520">[470]</a></sup> The Smriti texts of the period between 200 BCE-100 CE affirmed the authority of the Vedas. The acceptance of the ideas in the Vedas and Upanishads became a central criterium for defining Hinduism, while the heterodox movements rejected those ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200714_521-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200714-521">[471]</a></sup></p>
<p>The major Sanskrit epics, <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a></i>, which belong to the Smriti, were compiled over a protracted period during the late centuries BCE and the early centuries CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_442-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-442">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[web 12]</a></sup> These are legendary dialogues interspersed with philosophical treatises. The <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> was composed in this period and consolidated diverse philosophies and soteriological ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200720_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200720-523">[472]</a></sup></p>
<p>During this period, the foundational texts of several schools of Hindu philosophy were formally written down, including <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>, Yoga, <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purva-Mimamsa" title="Purva-Mimamsa">Purva-Mimamsa</a> and Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radhaxviii-xxi_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-Radhaxviii-xxi-524">[473]</a></sup> The Smriti literature of Hinduism, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">Sutras</a>, as well as other Hindu texts such as the <a href="/wiki/Arthashastra" title="Arthashastra">Arthashastra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sushruta_Samhita" title="Sushruta Samhita">Sushruta Samhita</a> were also written or expanded during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_442-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-442">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[474]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many influential Yoga Upanishads, states Gavin Flood, were composed before 3rd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199696_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199696-526">[475]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[476]</a></sup> Seven Sannyasa Upanishads of Hinduism were composed between the last centuries of the 1st millennium BCE and before the 3rd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[478]</a></sup> All these texts describe Hindu renunciation and monastic values, and express strongly Advaita Vedanta tradition ideas. This, state Patrick Olivelle and other scholars, is likely because the monasteries of Advaita tradition of Hinduism had become well established in ancient times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[481]</a></sup> The first version of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natyasastra" title="Natyasastra">Natyasastra</a> – a Hindu text on performance arts that integrates Vedic ideology – was also completed before the 2nd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[483]</a></sup></p>
<dl>
<dt>"Golden Age" (Gupta Empire) (c. 320–650 CE)</dt>
</dl>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta period</a>, the first stone and cave Hindu temples dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">Hindu deities</a> were built, some of which have survived into the modern era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440-535">[484]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[note 33]</a></sup> Numerous monasteries and universities were also built during the Gupta dynasty era, which supported Vedic and non-Vedic studies, including the famed <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-538">[486]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[487]</a></sup></p>
<p>The first version of early Puranas, likely composed between 250 and 500 CE, show continuities with the Vedic religion, but also an expanded mythology of Vishnu, Shiva and Devi (goddess).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[488]</a></sup> The Puranas were living texts that were revised over time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[489]</a></sup> and Lorenzen suggests these texts may reflect the beginnings of "medieval Hinduism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636_110-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636-110">[94]</a></sup></p>
<dl>
<dt>Late-Classical Hinduism - Puranic Hinduism (c. 650–1100 CE)</dt>
</dl>
<p>After the end of the Gupta Empire, power became decentralised in India. The disintegration of central power also led to regionalisation of religiosity, and religious rivalry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-542">[490]</a></sup> Rural and devotional movements arose within Hinduism, along with <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaisnavism" title="Vaisnavism">Vaisnavism</a>, Bhakti and Tantra,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_542-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-542">[490]</a></sup> that competed with each other, as well as with numerous sects of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_542-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-542">[490]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInden197867_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInden197867-543">[491]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="Decline of Buddhism in India">Buddhism declined</a>, though many of its ideas, and even the Buddha himself, were absorbed into certain Brahmanical traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lal_disappearance_544-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lal_disappearance-544">[492]</a></sup></p>
<p>Srauta rituals declined in India and were replaced with Buddhist and Hindu initiatory rituals for royal courts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[493]</a></sup> Over time, some Buddhist practices were integrated into Hinduism, monumental Hindu temples were built in South Asia and Southeast Asia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michell1977_546-0"><a href="#cite_note-Michell1977-546">[494]</a></sup> while Vajrayana Buddhism literature developed as a result of royal courts sponsoring both Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Saivism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[495]</a></sup></p>
<p>The first edition of many Puranas were composed in this period. Examples include <a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vishnu_Purana" title="Vishnu Purana">Vishnu Purana</a> with legends of Krishna,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986138-151_548-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986138-151-548">[496]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Padma_Purana" title="Padma Purana">Padma Purana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kurma_Purana" title="Kurma Purana">Kurma Purana</a> expressed reverence for Vishnu, Shiva and Shakti with equal enthusiasm;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986185_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986185-549">[497]</a></sup> all of them included topics such as Yoga practice and pilgrimage tour guides to Hindu holy sites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986158-160_550-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986158-160-550">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[499]</a></sup> Early colonial era orientalists proposed that the Puranas were religious texts of medieval Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ursapp331_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-ursapp331-552">[500]</a></sup> However, modern era scholars, such as Urs App, Ronald Inden and Ludo Rocher state that this is highly misleading because these texts were continuously revised, exist in numerous very different versions and are too inconsistent to be religious texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ursapp331_552-1"><a href="#cite_note-ursapp331-552">[500]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986104-106_with_footnotes.2C_Quote:_.22I_want_to_stress_the_fact_that_it_would_be_irresponsible_and_highly_misleading_to_speak_of_or_pretend_to_describe_the_religion_of_the_Puranas..22_553-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986104-106_with_footnotes.2C_Quote:_.22I_want_to_stress_the_fact_that_it_would_be_irresponsible_and_highly_misleading_to_speak_of_or_pretend_to_describe_the_religion_of_the_Puranas..22-553">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[502]</a></sup></p>
<p>Bhakti ideas centered around loving devotion to Vishnu and Shiva with songs and music, were pioneered in this period by the Alvars and Nayanars of South India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[504]</a></sup> Major Hinduism scholars of this period included <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a>, Maṇḍana-Miśra, Padmapada and Sureśvara of the Advaita schools;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEComans2000_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEComans2000-557">[505]</a></sup> Sabara, Vatsyayana and Samkarasvamin of <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a>-Vaisesika schools; Mathara and <i>Yuktidipika</i> (author unknown) of <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>-<a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>; Bhartrhari, Vasugupta and <a href="/wiki/Abhinavagupta" title="Abhinavagupta">Abhinavagupta</a> of Kashmir Shaivism, and <a href="/wiki/Ramanuja" title="Ramanuja">Ramanuja</a> of Vishishtadvaita school of Hinduism (Sri Vaishnavism).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680_560-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680-560">[508]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Islamic_rule_and_Bhakti_movement_of_Hinduism_(c._1200–1750_CE)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_rule_and_Bhakti_movement_of_Hinduism_.28c._1200.E2.80.931750_CE.29">Islamic rule and Bhakti movement of Hinduism (c. 1200–1750 CE)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_India" title="Islam in India">Islam in India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1799" data-file-width="1186" height="334" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/220px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/330px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/440px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a> visits a Hindu temple.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The Islamic rule period witnessed Hindu-Muslim confrontation and violence,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985_561-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985-561">[509]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140-562">[510]</a></sup> but "violence did not normally characterize the relations of <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> and Hindu."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995110_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995110-563">[511]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62_564-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62-564">[512]</a></sup> Enslavement of non-Muslims, especially Hindus in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, was part of the Muslim raids and conquests,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16.2C_61-62.2C_172-174_565-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16.2C_61-62.2C_172-174-565">[513]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12-566">[514]</a></sup> but after the 14th century slavery become less common,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199162_567-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199162-567">[515]</a></sup> and in 1562 "Akbar abolished the practice of enslaving the families of war captives."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611_568-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-568">[516]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a> recognized Hinduism, protected Hindu temples, and abolished discriminatory <a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">Jizya</a> (head taxes) against Hindus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12_566-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12-566">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118-569">[517]</a></sup> but occasionally, Muslim rulers of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, before and after Akbar, from 12th century to 18th century, destroyed Hindu temples<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271-570">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115_572-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115-572">[520]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[note 34]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Hindus" title="Persecution of Hindus">persecuted non-Muslims</a>.</p>
<p>Though Islam came to Indian subcontinent in the early 7th century with the advent of Arab traders, it started impacting Indian religions after the 10th century, and particularly after the 12th century with the establishment and then expansion of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Muslim conquest in the Indian subcontinent">Islamic rule</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasham1999_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasham1999-574">[521]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384-575">[522]</a></sup> During this period Buddhism declined rapidly, and a distinct Indo-Islamic culture emerged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109-576">[523]</a></sup> Under Akbar an "intriguing blend of Perso-Islamic and Rajput-Hindu traditions became manifest."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_577-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995111-577">[524]</a></sup> Nevertheless, many orthodox <i>ulamas</i> ("learned Islamic jurists") opposed the rapprochement of Hinduism and Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_577-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995111-577">[524]</a></sup> and the two merely co-existed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_578-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995112-578">[525]</a></sup> although there was more accommodation at the peasantry level of Indian society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_578-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995112-578">[525]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to Hardy, the Muslim rulers were not concerned with the number of converts, since the stability and continuity of their regime did not depend on the number of Muslims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHardy1977_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHardy1977-579">[526]</a></sup> In general, religious conversion was a gradual process, with some converts attracted to pious Muslim saints, while others converted to Islam to gain tax relief, land grant, marriage partners, social and economic advancement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187_580-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187-580">[527]</a></sup> or freedom from slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari201366-70_581-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari201366-70-581">[528]</a></sup> In border regions such as the Punjab and eastern Bengal, the share of Muslims grew as large as 70% to 90% of the population, whereas in the heartland of Muslim rule, the upper Gangetic Plain, the Muslims constituted only 10 to 15% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[note 35]</a></sup></p>
<p>Between the 14th and 18th century, Hinduism was revived in certain provinces of India under two powerful states, viz. <i><a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha</a></i>. The 14th and 15th century <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">Southern India</a> saw the rise of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vijayanagar_Empire" title="Vijayanagar Empire">Hindu Vijayanagar Empire</a>, which served as a barrier against invasion by the Muslim sultanates of the north, and it fostered the reconstruction of Hindu life and administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[web 13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vidyaranya" title="Vidyaranya">Vidyaranya</a>, also known as Madhava, who was the 12th Jagadguru of the Śringeri Śarada Pītham from 1380-6,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[529]</a></sup> and a minister in the Vijayanagara Empire,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-talbot_585-0"><a href="#cite_note-talbot-585">[530]</a></sup> helped establish Shankara as a rallying symbol of values, and helped spread historical and cultural influence of Shankara's Vedanta philosophies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199529-30_586-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199529-30-586">[531]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blakemichael_587-0"><a href="#cite_note-blakemichael-587">[532]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Hindu Maratha Confederacy</a> rose to power in the 18th century and ended up overthrowing Muslim power in India<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[533]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[534]</a></sup></p>
<p>Hinduism underwent profound changes, aided in part by teachers such as <a href="/wiki/Ramanuja" title="Ramanuja">Ramanuja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madhvacharya" title="Madhvacharya">Madhva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Mahaprabhu" title="Chaitanya Mahaprabhu">Chaitanya</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-.7B.7BISBN.7C0-19-563921-9.7D.7D_590-0"><a href="#cite_note-.7B.7BISBN.7C0-19-563921-9.7D.7D-590">[535]</a></sup> Tantra disappeared in northern India, partly due to Muslim rule,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood200634_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood200634-591">[536]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a> grew, with followers engaging in emotional, passionate and community-oriented devotional worship, participating in <i>saguna</i> or <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nirguna_Brahman" title="Nirguna Brahman">nirguna Brahman</a></i> ideologies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[537]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JordensISBN_0-19-563921-9_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-JordensISBN_0-19-563921-9-593">[538]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[539]</a></sup> According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th century, "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the "six systems" (<i>saddarsana</i>) of mainstream Hindu philosophy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson20102_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson20102-113">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[note 36]</a></sup> Michaels notes that a historicization emerged which preceded later nationalism, articulating ideas which glorified Hinduism and the past.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444_119-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444-119">[102]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Modern_Hinduism_(from_circa_1800)"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_Hinduism_.28from_circa_1800.29">Modern Hinduism (from circa 1800)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1071" data-file-width="1600" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg/220px-Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg/330px-Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg/440px-Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rath_Yatra_russia_winter.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russian_people" title="Russian people">Russian</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krishnaism" title="Krishnaism">Krishnaites</a> celebrating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ratha_Yatra" title="Ratha Yatra">Ratha Yatra</a>. In the late 20th century forms of Hinduism have grown indigenous roots in parts of Russia, significantly in <a href="/wiki/Altai_Republic" title="Altai Republic">Altay</a> where Hinduism is now the religion of 2% of the population.</div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_revivalism">Hindu revivalism</span></h4>
<p>With the onset of the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>, the colonization of India by the British, there also started a <a href="/wiki/Bengali_renaissance" title="Bengali renaissance">Hindu renaissance</a> in the 19th century, which profoundly changed the understanding of Hinduism in both India and the west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002_596-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002-596">[540]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indology" title="Indology">Indology</a> as an academic discipline of studying Indian culture from a European perspective was established in the 19th century, led by scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Max_M%C3%BCller" title="Max Müller">Max Müller</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Woodroffe" title="John Woodroffe">John Woodroffe</a>. They brought Vedic, Puranic and Tantric literature and philosophy to Europe and the United States. Western <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">orientalist</a> searched for the "essence" of the Indian religions, discerning this in the Vedas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002118_597-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002118-597">[541]</a></sup> and meanwhile creating the notion of "Hinduism" as a unified body of religious praxis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B_598-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B-598">[542]</a></sup> and the popular picture of 'mystical India'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B_598-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B-598">[542]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002_596-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002-596">[540]</a></sup> This idea of a Vedic essence was taken over by Hindu reform movements as the <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a>, which was supported for a while by the <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarian Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006114_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006114-599">[543]</a></sup> together with the ideas of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universalism_in_religion" title="Universalism in religion">Universalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perennial_philosophy" title="Perennial philosophy">Perennialism</a>, the idea that all religions share a common <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystic</a> ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002119-120_600-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002119-120-600">[544]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">"Hindu modernism"</a>, with proponents like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vivekananda" title="Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aurobindo" title="Aurobindo">Aurobindo</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Radhakrishnan" title="Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan</a>, became central in the popular understanding of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002123_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002123-601">[545]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuesse20113-4_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuesse20113-4-602">[546]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger201018_603-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger201018-603">[547]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJouhki200610-11_604-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJouhki200610-11-604">[548]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Popularity_in_the_west">Popularity in the west</span></h4>
<p>Influential 20th-century Hindus were <a href="/wiki/Ramana_Maharshi" title="Ramana Maharshi">Ramana Maharshi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B.K.S._Iyengar" title="B.K.S. Iyengar">B.K.S. Iyengar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paramahansa_Yogananda" title="Paramahansa Yogananda">Paramahansa Yogananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._C._Bhaktivedanta_Swami_Prabhupada" title="A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada">Prabhupada</a> (founder of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISKCON" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>), <a href="/wiki/Sri_Chinmoy" title="Sri Chinmoy">Sri Chinmoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swami_Rama" title="Swami Rama">Swami Rama</a> and others who translated, reformulated and presented Hinduism's foundational texts for contemporary audiences in new iterations, raising the profiles of Yoga and Vedanta in the West and attracting followers and attention in India and abroad.</p>
<p>Hindu practices such as Yoga, Ayurvedic health, Tantric sexuality through <a href="/wiki/Neotantra" title="Neotantra">Neotantra</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Kama_Sutra" title="Kama Sutra">Kama Sutra</a></i> have spread beyond Hindu communities and have been accepted by several non-Hindus:</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">
<p>Hinduism is attracting Western adherents through the affiliated practice of yoga. Yoga centers in the West—which generally advocate vegetarianism—attract young, well-educated Westerners who are drawn by yoga's benefits for the physical and emotional health; there they are introduced to the Hindu philosophical system taught by most yoga teachers, known as Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[549]</a></sup></p>
</blockquote>
<p>It is estimated that around 30 million Americans and 5 million Europeans regularly practice some form of Hatha Yoga.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[550]</a></sup> In Australia, the number of practitioners is about 300,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[web 14]</a></sup> In New Zealand the number is also around 300,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[web 15]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindutva">Hindutva</span></h4>
<p>In the 20th century, Hinduism also gained prominence as a political force and a source for national identity in India. With origins traced back to the establishment of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> in the 1910s, the movement grew with the formulation and development of the <a href="/wiki/Hindutva" title="Hindutva">Hindutva</a> ideology in the following decades; the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh</a> (RSS) in 1925; and the entry, and later success, of RSS offshoots <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jana_Sangha" title="Jana Sangha">Jana Sangha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">Bharatiya Janata Party</a> (BJP) in electoral politics in post-independence India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ram-Prasad_609-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ram-Prasad-609">[551]</a></sup> Hindu religiosity plays an important role in the nationalist movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart2004196-197_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart2004196-197-610">[552]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[note 37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-neo_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-neo-616">[note 38]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">Hinduism by country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">

The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_Temple_of_Besakih" title="Mother Temple of Besakih">Mother Temple of Besakih</a>, one of the most significant <a href="/wiki/Balinese_Hinduism" title="Balinese Hinduism">Hindu</a> temples in <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.</div>

<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Hinduism_by_country" title="Template:Hinduism by country"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>

<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Hinduism_by_country&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
