</table>
<p>Hinduism is a major religion in India. Hinduism was followed by around 79.8% of the country's population of 1.21 billion (2011 census) (960 million adherents).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[web 16]</a></sup> Other <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">significant populations</a> are found in Nepal (23 million), Bangladesh (15 million) and the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesian</a> island of <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> (3.9 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bps_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-bps-618">[557]</a></sup> The majority of the Vietnamese <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cham_people" title="Cham people">Cham people</a> also follow Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-619"><a href="#cite_note-619">[558]</a></sup></p>
<p>Countries with the greatest proportion of Hindus (as of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hinduism&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>):</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" data-file-height="885" data-file-width="726" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/16px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/25px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/33px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>   </span><a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> 81.3%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[web 17]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1350" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/23px-Flag_of_India.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/35px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/45px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> 79.8%</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="450" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/35px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/45px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a> 51.9%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[559]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="500" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/23px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/35px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/46px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a> 28.4%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[web 18]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/23px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/35px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/46px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> 27.9%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[web 19]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a> 25%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[web 20]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/23px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/35px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/45px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a> 20%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[web 21]</a></sup></li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="500" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/46px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> 9.6%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[web 23]</a></sup></li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/R%C3%A9union" title="Réunion">Réunion</a> 6.7%</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2800" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> 6.3%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_629-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-629">[web 24]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1500" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/46px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a> 6.25%</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/23px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/35px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/46px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a> 6%</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2880" data-file-width="4320" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/23px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/35px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/45px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a> 5.1%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010_census_Full_report_630-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010_census_Full_report-630">[web 25]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> 5%</li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="750" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Flag_of_Belize.svg/23px-Flag_of_Belize.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Flag_of_Belize.svg/35px-Flag_of_Belize.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Flag_of_Belize.svg/45px-Flag_of_Belize.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">Belize</a> 2.3%</li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="900" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/23px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/35px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/46px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png 2x" width="23"/> </span><a href="/wiki/Seychelles" title="Seychelles">Seychelles</a> 2.1%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[web 26]</a></sup></li>
</ol>
<p>Demographically, Hinduism is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's third largest religion</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632"><a href="#cite_note-632">[561]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conversion_debate">Conversion debate</span></h3>
<p>In the modern era, religious conversion from and to Hinduism has been a controversial subject. Some state the concept of missionary conversion, either way, is anathema to the precepts of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_633-0"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-633">[562]</a></sup></p>
<p>Religious conversion to Hinduism has a long history outside India. Merchants and traders of India, particularly from the Indian peninsula, carried their religious ideas, which led to religious conversions to Hinduism in southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[563]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-635"><a href="#cite_note-635">[564]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-636"><a href="#cite_note-636">[565]</a></sup> Within India, archeological and textual evidence such as the 2nd century BCE <a href="/wiki/Heliodorus_pillar" title="Heliodorus pillar">Heliodorus pillar</a> suggest that Greeks and other foreigners converted to Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637"><a href="#cite_note-637">[566]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-638"><a href="#cite_note-638">[567]</a></sup> The debate on proselytization and religious conversion between Christianity, Islam and Hinduism is more recent, and started in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rafiuddinahmed_639-0"><a href="#cite_note-rafiuddinahmed-639">[568]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ayeshajalal_640-0"><a href="#cite_note-ayeshajalal-640">[569]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-644"><a href="#cite_note-644">[note 39]</a></sup></p>
<p>Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Arya_Samaj" title="Arya Samaj">Arya Samaj</a> launched <i>Shuddhi</i> movement to proselytize and reconvert Muslims and Christians back to Hinduism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csadcock_643-1"><a href="#cite_note-csadcock-643">[572]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[573]</a></sup> while those such as the <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a> suggested Hinduism to be a non-missionary religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_633-1"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-633">[562]</a></sup> All these sects of Hinduism have welcomed new members to their group, while other leaders of Hinduism's diverse schools have stated that given the intensive proselytization activities from missionary Islam and Christianity, this "there is no such thing as proselytism in Hinduism" view must be re-examined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_633-2"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-633">[562]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csadcock_643-2"><a href="#cite_note-csadcock-643">[572]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646"><a href="#cite_note-646">[574]</a></sup></p>
<p>The appropriateness of conversion from major religions to Hinduism, and vice versa, has been and remains an actively debated topic in India,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647"><a href="#cite_note-647">[575]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-648"><a href="#cite_note-648">[576]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-649"><a href="#cite_note-649">[577]</a></sup> and in Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamstedt200493-108_.28Robert_Hefner.29_650-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamstedt200493-108_.28Robert_Hefner.29-650">[578]</a></sup></p>

<p><b>Related systems and religions</b></p>
<div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-3" style="-moz-column-count: 3; -webkit-column-count: 3; column-count: 3;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ayyavazhi" title="Ayyavazhi">Ayyavazhi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-definition-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-definition_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-definition_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Hinduism is variously defined as a "religion", "set of religious beliefs and practices", "religious tradition", "a way of life" (<a href="#CITEREFSharma2003">Sharma 2003</a>, pp. 12–13) etc. For a discussion on the topic, see: "Establishing the boundaries" in <a href="#CITEREFFlood2008">Flood 2008</a>, pp. 1–17</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See:</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">Fowler: "probably the oldest religion in the world" (<a href="#CITEREFFowler1997">Fowler 1997</a>, p. 1)</span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Klostermaier: The "oldest living major religion" in the world (<a href="#CITEREFKlostermaier2007">Klostermaier 2007</a>, p. 1)</span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Kurien: "There are almost a billion Hindus living on Earth. They practice the world's oldest religion..." <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[1]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Bakker: "it [Hinduism] is the oldest religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[2]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Noble: "Hinduism, the world's oldest surviving religion, continues to provide the framework for daily life in much of South Asia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[3]</a></sup></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lockard-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Lockard_8-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lockard_8-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Lockard_8-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLockard2007">Lockard 2007</a>, p. 50: "The encounters that resulted from Aryan migration brought together several very different peoples and cultures, reconfiguring Indian society. Over many centuries a fusion of <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Aryan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dravidian_peoples" title="Dravidian peoples">Dravidian</a> occurred, a complex process that historians have labeled the Indo-Aryan synthesis." <a href="#CITEREFLockard2007">Lockard 2007</a>, p. 52: "Hinduism can be seen historically as a synthesis of Aryan beliefs with Harappan and other Dravidian traditions that developed over many centuries."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHiltebeitel2007">Hiltebeitel 2007</a>, p. 12: "A period of consolidation, sometimes identified as one of "Hindu synthesis," Brahmanic synthesis," or "orthodox synthesis," takes place between the time of the late Vedic Upanishads (c. 500 BCE) and the period of Gupta imperial ascendency" (c. 320-467 CE)."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-fusion-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-fusion_12-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-fusion_12-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-fusion_12-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">See also:</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">J.H. Hutton (1931), in <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFGhurye1980">Ghurye, Govind Sadashiv (1980), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pTNmCIc9hCUC&amp;dq=australoids+india+religion&amp;hl=nl&amp;source=gbs_navlinks_s" rel="nofollow"><i>The Scheduled Tribes of India</i></a>, Transaction Publishers, pp. 3–4</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Govind+Sadashiv&amp;rft.aulast=Ghurye&amp;rft.btitle=The+Scheduled+Tribes+of+India&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=3-4&amp;rft.pub=Transaction+Publishers&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DpTNmCIc9hCUC%26dq%3Daustraloids%2Bindia%2Breligion%26hl%3Dnl%26source%3Dgbs_navlinks_s&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[subnote 1]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFZimmer1951">Zimmer, Heinrich (1951), <i>Philosophies of India</i>, Princeton University Press, pp. 218–219</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Heinrich&amp;rft.aulast=Zimmer&amp;rft.btitle=Philosophies+of+India&amp;rft.date=1951&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=218-219&amp;rft.pub=Princeton+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li>Tyler (1973), <i>India: An Anthropological Perspective</i>, Goodyear Publishing Company. In: <a href="#CITEREFSjoberg1990">Sjoberg 1990</a>, p. 43<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[subnote 2]</a></sup></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFSjoberg1990">Sjoberg, Andree F. (1990), <a class="external text" href="https://ojs.lib.byu.edu/spc/index.php/CCR/article/download/13469/13403" rel="nofollow">"The Dravidian Contribution To The Development Of Indian Civilization: A Call For A Reassesment"</a>, <i>Comparative Civilizations Review</i>, <b>23</b>: 40–74</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=The+Dravidian+Contribution+To+The+Development+Of+Indian+Civilization%3A+A+Call+For+A+Reassesment&amp;rft.aufirst=Andree+F.&amp;rft.aulast=Sjoberg&amp;rft.date=1990&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Comparative+Civilizations+Review&amp;rft.pages=40-74&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fojs.lib.byu.edu%2Fspc%2Findex.php%2FCCR%2Farticle%2Fdownload%2F13469%2F13403&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-93">[78]</a></sup></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFNath2001">Nath, Vijay (2001), "From 'Brahmanism' to 'Hinduism': Negotiating the Myth of the Great Tradition", <i>Social Scientist</i>: 19–50</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=From+%27Brahmanism%27+to+%27Hinduism%27%3A+Negotiating+the+Myth+of+the+Great+Tradition&amp;rft.aufirst=Vijay&amp;rft.aulast=Nath&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Scientist&amp;rft.pages=19-50&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFWerner1998">Werner, Karel (1998), <i>Yoga And Indian Philosophy (1977, Reprinted in 1998)</i>, Motilal Banarsidass Publ, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/81-208-1609-9" title="Special:BookSources/81-208-1609-9">81-208-1609-9</a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Karel&amp;rft.aulast=Werner&amp;rft.btitle=Yoga+And+Indian+Philosophy+%281977%2C+Reprinted+in+1998%29&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=81-208-1609-9&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass+Publ&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFWerner2005">Werner, karel (2005), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HvuQAgAAQBAJ&amp;dq=hinduism+synthesis&amp;hl=nl&amp;source=gbs_navlinks_s" rel="nofollow"><i>A Popular Dictionary of Hinduism</i></a>, Routledge, pp. 8–9</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=karel&amp;rft.aulast=Werner&amp;rft.btitle=A+Popular+Dictionary+of+Hinduism&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=8-9&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DHvuQAgAAQBAJ%26dq%3Dhinduism%2Bsynthesis%26hl%3Dnl%26source%3Dgbs_navlinks_s&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFLockard2007">Lockard, Craig A. (2007), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=yJPlCpzOY_QC&amp;pg=PA50" rel="nofollow"><i>Societies, Networks, and Transitions. Volume I: to 1500</i></a>, Cengage Learning, p. 50</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Craig+A.&amp;rft.aulast=Lockard&amp;rft.btitle=Societies%2C+Networks%2C+and+Transitions.+Volume+I%3A+to+1500&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=50&amp;rft.pub=Cengage+Learning&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DyJPlCpzOY_QC%26pg%3DPA50&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel2007frontcover_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel2007frontcover-94">[79]</a></sup></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFHopfeWoodward2008">Hopfe, Lewis M.; Woodward, Mark R. (2008), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=BVbiMBDVrdEC&amp;pg=PA79" rel="nofollow"><i>Religions of the World</i></a>, Pearson Education, p. 79</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Woodward%2C+Mark+R.&amp;rft.aufirst=Lewis+M.&amp;rft.aulast=Hopfe&amp;rft.btitle=Religions+of+the+World&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=79&amp;rft.pub=Pearson+Education&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DBVbiMBDVrdEC%26pg%3DPA79&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hopfe_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hopfe-95">[subnote 3]</a></sup></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFSamuel2010">Samuel, Geoffrey (2010), <i>The Origins of Yoga and Tantra. Indic Religions to the Thirteenth Century</i>, Cambridge University Press</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Geoffrey&amp;rft.aulast=Samuel&amp;rft.btitle=The+Origins+of+Yoga+and+Tantra.+Indic+Religions+to+the+Thirteenth+Century&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Among its roots are the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic religion</a> of the late <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> (<a href="#CITEREFFlood1996">Flood 1996</a>, p. 16) and its emphasis on the status of Brahmans (<a href="#CITEREFSamuel2010">Samuel 2010</a>, pp. 48–53), but also the religions of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a> (<a href="#CITEREFNarayanan2009">Narayanan 2009</a>, p. 11; <a href="#CITEREFLockard2007">Lockard 2007</a>, p. 52; <a href="#CITEREFHiltebeitel2007">Hiltebeitel 2007</a>, p. 3; <a href="#CITEREFJonesRyan2006">Jones &amp; Ryan 2006</a>, p. xviii) the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sramana" title="Sramana">Sramana</a> or renouncer traditions of <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">north-east India</a> (<a href="#CITEREFFlood1996">Flood 1996</a>, p. 16; <a href="#CITEREFGomez2013">Gomez 2013</a>, p. 42) and "popular or <a href="/wiki/Adivasi" title="Adivasi">local traditions</a>" (<a href="#CITEREFFlood1996">Flood 1996</a>, p. 16).</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Indo-Aryan word <i>Sindhu</i> means "river", "ocean".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20083_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20083-33">[25]</a></sup> It is frequently being used in the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>. The Sindhu-area is part of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80ry%C4%81varta" title="Āryāvarta">Āryāvarta</a>, "the land of the Aryans".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-44">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There are several views on the earliest mention of 'Hindu' in the context of religion:</span>
<ol>
<li><span class="reference-text">Gavin Flood (1996) states: "In Arabic texts, Al-Hind is a term used for the people of modern-day India and 'Hindu', or 'Hindoo', was used towards the end of the eighteenth century by the British to refer to the people of 'Hindustan', the people of northwest India. Eventually 'Hindu' became virtually equivalent to an 'Indian' who was not a Muslim, Sikh, Jain or Christian, thereby encompassing a range of religious beliefs and practices. The '-ism' was added to Hindu in around 1830 to denote the culture and religion of the high-caste Brahmans in contrast to other religions, and the term was soon appropriated by Indians themselves in the context of building a national identity opposed to colonialism, though the term 'Hindu' was used in Sanskrit and Bengali hagiographic texts in contrast to 'Yavana' or Muslim as early as the sixteenth century".(<a href="#CITEREFFlood1996">Flood 1996</a>, p. 6)</span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Arvind_Sharma" title="Arvind Sharma">Arvind Sharma</a> (2002) and other scholars state that the 7th-century Chinese scholar <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>, whose 17 year travel to India and interactions with its people and religions were recorded and preserved in Chinese language, uses the transliterated term <i>In-tu</i> whose "connotation overflows in the religious".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh-36">[27]</a></sup> Xuanzang describes <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu Deva-temples</a> of early 7th century CE, worship of <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Sun</a> deity and <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>, his debates with scholars of Samkhya and Vaisheshika schools of Hindu philosophies, monks and monasteries of Hindus, Jains and Buddhists (both Mahayana and Theravada), and the study of the Vedas along with Buddhist texts at <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[30]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Arvind Sharma (2002) also mentions the use of word <i>Hindu</i> in Islamic texts such those relating to 8th-century Arab invasion of Sindh by Muhammad ibn Qasim, Al Biruni's 11th-century text <i>Tarikh Al-Hind</i>, and those of the Delhi Sultanate period, where the term <i>Hindu</i> retains the ambiguities of including all non-Islamic people such as Buddhists and of being "a region or a religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh2_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh2-40">[31]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/David_Lorenzen" title="David Lorenzen">David Lorenzen</a> (2006) states, citing Richard Eaton: "one of the earliest occurrences of the word 'Hindu' in Islamic literature appears in 'Abd al-Malik Isami's Persian work, <i>Futuhu's-salatin</i>, composed in the Deccan in 1350. In this text, 'Isami uses the word 'hindi' to mean Indian in the ethno-geographical sense and the word 'hindu' to mean 'Hindu' in the sense of a follower of the Hindu religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[32]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">David Lorenzen (2006) also mentions other non-Persian texts such as <i>Prithvíráj Ráso</i> by ~12th century Canda Baradai, and epigraphical inscription evidence from Andhra Pradesh kingdoms who battled military expansion of Muslim dynasties in 14th century, where the word 'Hindu' partly implies a religious identity in contrast to 'Turks' or Islamic religious identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[33]</a></sup> One of the earliest uses of word 'Hindu' in religious context, in a European language (Spanish), was the publication in 1649 by Sebastiao Manrique.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[34]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In ancient literature the name <i>Bharata</i> or <i>Bharata Vrasa</i> was being used.(<a href="#CITEREFGarg1992">Garg 1992</a>, p. 3)</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sweetman mentions:</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">Wilhelm Halbfass (1988), <i>India and Europe</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">IXth European Conference on Modern Asian Studies in Heidelberg (1989), <i>Hinduism Reconsidered</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Ronald_Inden" title="Ronald Inden">Ronald Inden</a>, <i>Imagining India</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Carol_Breckenridge" title="Carol Breckenridge">Carol Breckenridge</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_van_der_Veer" title="Peter van der Veer">Peter van der Veer</a>, <i>Orientalism and the Postcolonial Predicament</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Vasudha Dalmia and <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_von_Stietencron" title="Heinrich von Stietencron">Heinrich von Stietencron</a>, <i>Representing Hinduism</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S.N._Balagangadhara" title="S.N. Balagangadhara">S.N. Balagangadhara</a>, <i>The Heathen in his Blindness...</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Thomas_Trautmann" title="Thomas Trautmann">Thomas Trautmann</a>, <i>Aryans and British India</i></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Richard King (1989), <i>Orientalism and religion</i></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Rajiv_Malhotra" title="Rajiv Malhotra">Rajiv Malhotra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Being_Different" title="Being Different">Being Different</a> for a critic who gained widespread attention outside the academia, <a href="/wiki/Invading_the_Sacred" title="Invading the Sacred">Invading the Sacred</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_studies" title="Hindu studies">Hindu studies</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See also Arvind Sharma (2002), <i>On Hindu, Hindustān, Hinduism and Hindutva</i>. Numen Vol. 49, Fasc. 1 (2002), pp. 1-36.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-125"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-125">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Pennington<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[107]</a></sup> describes the circumstances in which early impressions of Hinduism were reported by colonial era missionaries: "Missionary reports from India also reflected the experience of foreigners in a land whose native inhabitants and British rulers often resented their presence. Their accounts of Hinduism were forged in physically, politically and spiritually hostile surroundings [impoverished, famine prone Bengal - now West Bengal and Bangladesh]. Plagued with anxieties and fears about their own health, regularly reminded of colleagues who had lost their lives or reason, uncertain of their own social location, and preaching to crowds whose reactions ranged from indifference to amusement to hostility, missionaries found expression for their darker misgivings in their production of what is surely part of their speckled legacy: a fabricated Hinduism crazed by blood-lust and devoted to the service of devils."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-136"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-136">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sweetman identifies several areas in which "there is substantial, if not universal, agreement that colonialism influenced the study of Hinduism, even if the degree of this influence is debated":<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup></span>
<ol>
<li><span class="reference-text">The wish of European Orientalists "to establish a textual basis for Hinduism," akin to the Protestant culture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup> which was also driven by a preference among the colonial powers for "written authority" rather than "oral authority."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">The influence of <a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a> on European conceptions of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">[T]he identification of Vedanta, more specifically <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, as 'the paradigmatic example of the mystical nature of the Hindu religion'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[subnote 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413_127-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-127">[109]</a></sup> Several factors led to the favouring of Vedanta as the "central philosophy of the Hindus":<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-14_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-14-129">[110]</a></sup></span>
<ol>
<li><span class="reference-text">According to Niranjan Dhar's theory that Vedanta was favored because British feared French influence, especially the impact of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>; and Ronald Inden's theory that Advaita Vedanta was portrayed as 'illusionist pantheism' reinforcing the colonial stereotypical construction of Hinduism as indifferent to ethics and life-negating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-14_129-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200413-14-129">[110]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">"The amenability of Vedantic thought to both Christian and Hindu critics of 'idolatry' in other forms of Hinduism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200414_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200414-130">[111]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
<li><span class="reference-text">The colonial constructions of caste as being part of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200414-16_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200414-16-131">[112]</a></sup> According to Nicholas Dirks' theory that, "Caste was refigured as a religious system, organising society in a context where politics and religion had never before been distinct domains of social action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[subnote 5]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">"[T]he construction of Hinduism in the image of Christianity"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200415_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200415-133">[113]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Anti-colonial Hindus<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200415-16_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200415-16-134">[114]</a></sup> "looking toward the systematisation of disparate practices as a means of recovering a precolonial, national identity".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200415_133-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200415-133">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[subnote 6]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-144">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many scholars have presented pre-colonial common denominators and asserted the importance of ancient Hindu textual sources in medieval and pre-colonial times:</span>
<ol>
<li><span class="reference-text">Klaus Witz<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[116]</a></sup> states that Hindu <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a> ideas in the medieval era grew on the foundation of Upanishadic knowledge and Vedanta philosophies.</span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">John Henderson<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[117]</a></sup> states that "Hindus, both in medieval and in modern times, have been particularly drawn to those canonical texts and philosophical schools such as the Bhagavad Gita and Vedanta, which seem to synthesize or reconcile most successfully diverse philosophical teachings and sectarian points of view. Thus, this widely recognized attribute of Indian culture may be traced to the exegetical orientation of medieval Hindu commentarial traditions, especially Vedanta.</span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Patrick Olivelle<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[118]</a></sup> and others<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[121]</a></sup> state that the central ideas of the Upanishads in the Vedic corpus are at the spiritual core of Hindus.</span></li>
</ol>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For translation of <i>deva</i> in singular noun form as "a deity, god", and in plural form as "the gods" or "the heavenly or shining ones", see: <a href="#CITEREFMonier-Williams2001">Monier-Williams 2001</a>, p. 492. For translation of <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">devatā</span></i> as "godhead, divinity", see: <a href="#CITEREFMonier-Williams2001">Monier-Williams 2001</a>, p. 495.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-206"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-206">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Among some regional Hindus, such as Rajputs, these are called <i>Kuldevis</i> or <i>Kuldevata</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[180]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-avatars-207"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-avatars_207-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-avatars_207-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Lisa Hark, Lisa Hark, R.D., Horace DeLisser, MD (7 September 2011). <i>Achieving Cultural Competency</i>. John Wiley &amp; Sons. <q>Three gods, Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, and other deities are considered manifestations of and are worshipped as incarnations of Brahman.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Lisa+Hark%2C+Lisa+Hark%2C+R.D.%2C+Horace+DeLisser%2C+MD&amp;rft.btitle=Achieving+Cultural+Competency&amp;rft.date=2011-09-07&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Multiple_names:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list">link</a>)</span></span></li>
<li><a href="#CITEREFToropovBuckles2011">Toropov &amp; Buckles 2011</a>: The members of various Hindu sects worship a dizzying number of specific deities and follow innumerable rituals in honor of specific gods. Because this is Hinduism, however, its practitioners see the profusion of forms and practices as expressions of the same unchanging reality. The panoply of deities are understood by believers as symbols for a single transcendent reality.</li>
<li><cite class="citation book">Orlando O. Espín; James B. Nickoloff (2007). <i>An Introductory Dictionary of Theology and Religious Studies</i>. Liturgical Press. <q>The devas are powerful spiritual beings, somewhat like angels in the West, who have certain functions in the cosmos and live immensely long lives. Certain devas, such as Ganesha, are regularly worshiped by the Hindu faithful. Note that, while Hindus believe in many devas, many are monotheistic to the extent that they will recognise only one Supreme Being, a God or Goddess who is the source and ruler of the devas.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=James+B.+Nickoloff&amp;rft.au=Orlando+O.+Esp%C3%ADn&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introductory+Dictionary+of+Theology+and+Religious+Studies&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Liturgical+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-356"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-356">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Venkataraman and Deshpande: "Caste-based discrimination does exist in many parts of India today.... Caste-based discrimination fundamentally contradicts the essential teaching of Hindu sacred texts that divinity is inherent in all beings."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[web 9]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-428"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-428">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Different periods are designated as "classical Hinduism":</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">Smart calls the period between 1000 BCE and 100 CE "pre-classical". It is the formative period for the Upanishads and Brahmanism<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[subnote 7]</a></sup> Jainism and Buddhism. For Smart, the "classical period" lasts from 100 to 1000 CE, and coincides with the flowering of "classical Hinduism" and the flowering and deterioration of Mahayana-buddhism in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmart200352_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmart200352-424">[389]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">For Michaels, the period between 500 BCE and 200 BCE is a time of "Ascetic reformism",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200436_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200436-425">[390]</a></sup> whereas the period between 200 BCE and 1100 CE is the time of "classical Hinduism", since there is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200438_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200438-426">[391]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Muesse discerns a longer period of change, namely between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, which he calls the "Classical Period". According to Muesse, some of the fundamental concepts of Hinduism, namely karma, reincarnation and "personal enlightenment and transformation", which did not exist in the Vedic religion, developed in this time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuesse200314_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuesse200314-427">[392]</a></sup></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Vedic_composite-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Vedic_composite_432-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Vedic_composite_432-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">See:</span>
<ul>
<li><span class="reference-text">David Gordon White: "[T]he religion of the Vedas was already a composite of the indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200628_431-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200628-431">[395]</a></sup></span></li>
<li><span class="reference-text">Richard Gombrich: "It is important to bear in mind that the Indo-Aryans did not enter an unhabitated land. For nearly two millennia they and their culture gradually penetrated India, moving east and south from their original seat in the Punjab. They mixed with people who spoke Munda or Dravidian languages, who have left no traces of their culture beyond some archaeological remains; we know as little about them as we would about the Indo-Aryans if they had left no texts. (...) We can also assume that many - perhaps most - of the indigenous population came to be assimilated into Indo-Aryan culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199635-36_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199635-36-484">[438]</a></sup></span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-439"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-439">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tiwari mentions the <a href="/wiki/Australoid_race" title="Australoid race">Austric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongoloid" title="Mongoloid">Mongoloid</a> people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v-438">[401]</a></sup> See also <a href="/wiki/Peopling_of_India" title="Peopling of India">Peopling of India</a> for the variety of Indian people.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-444"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-444">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDoniger2010">Doniger 2010</a>, p. 66: "Much of what we now call Hinduism may have had roots in cultures that thrived in South Asia long before the creation of textual evidence that we can decipher with any confidence. Remarkable cave paintings have been preserved from Mesolithic sites dating from c. 30,000 BCE in <a href="/wiki/Bhimbetka_rock_shelters" title="Bhimbetka rock shelters">Bhimbetka</a>, near present-day Bhopal, in the Vindhya Mountains in the province of Madhya Pradesh."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-445"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-445">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFJonesRyan2006">Jones &amp; Ryan 2006</a>, p. xvii: "Some practices of Hinduism must have originated in Neolithic times (c. 4000 BCE). The worship of certain plants and animals as sacred, for instance, could very likely have very great antiquity. The worship of goddesses, too, a part of Hinduism today, may be a feature that originated in the Neolithic."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-451"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-451">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Michaels: "They called themselves <i>arya</i> ("Aryans," literally "the hospitable," from the Vedic <i>arya</i>, "homey, the hospitable") but even in the Rgveda, <i>arya</i> denotes a cultural and linguistic boundary and not only a racial one."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-454"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-454">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is no exact dating possible for the beginning of the Vedic period. Witzel mentions a range between 1900 and 1400 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel19953-4_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel19953-4-453">[411]</a></sup> Flood mentions 1500 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199621_421-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199621-421">[387]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-460"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-460">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aryan_migration_theory" title="Aryan migration theory">Aryan migration theory</a> has been challenged by some researchers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008186_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008186-458">[415]</a></sup> due to a lack of archaeological evidence and signs of cultural continuity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup> hypothesizing instead a slow process of acculturation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup> or transformation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35_456-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35-456">[413]</a></sup> Nevertheless, linguistic and archaeological data clearly show a cultural change after 1500 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_450-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-450">[409]</a></sup> with the linguistic and religious data clearly showing links with Indo-European languages and religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199633_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199633-459">[416]</a></sup> According to Singh, "The dominant view is that the Indo-Aryans came to the subcontinent as immigrants."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008186_458-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008186-458">[415]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-479"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-479">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Anthony, the Old Indic religion probably emerged among Indo-European immigrants in the contact zone between the <a href="/wiki/Zeravshan_River" title="Zeravshan River">Zeravshan River</a> (present-day Uzbekistan) and (present-day) Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007462_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007462-473">[429]</a></sup> It was "a syncretic mixture of old Central Asian and new Indo-European elements",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007462_473-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007462-473">[429]</a></sup> which borrowed "distinctive religious beliefs and practices"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beckwith2009p32_472-1"><a href="#cite_note-Beckwith2009p32-472">[428]</a></sup> from the <a href="/wiki/Bactria%E2%80%93Margiana_Archaeological_Complex" title="Bactria–Margiana Archaeological Complex">Bactria–Margiana Culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beckwith2009p32_472-2"><a href="#cite_note-Beckwith2009p32-472">[428]</a></sup> At least 383 non-Indo-European words were borrowed from this culture, including the god <a href="/wiki/Indra" title="Indra">Indra</a> and the ritual drink <a href="/wiki/Soma_(drink)" title="Soma (drink)">Soma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454-455_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454-455-474">[430]</a></sup> The oldest inscriptions in Old Indic, the language of the <i>Rig Veda</i>, are found not in northwestern India and Pakistan, but in northern Syria, the location of the Mitanni kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony200749_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony200749-475">[431]</a></sup> (...) The Old Indic term <a href="/wiki/%E1%B9%9Ata" title="Ṛta">r'ta</a>, meaning "cosmic order and truth", the central concept of the <i>Rig Veda</i>, was also employed in the mitanni kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony200749_475-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony200749-475">[431]</a></sup> And Old Indic gods, including <a href="/wiki/Indra" title="Indra">Indra</a>, were also known in the Mitanni kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony200750_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony200750-476">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood200868_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood200868-477">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeltonBaumann20101412_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeltonBaumann20101412-478">[434]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-498"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-498">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While some scholars suggest that Buddhism may have developed as a social reform to the Vedic religion, other scholars such as Gombrich suggest that Buddha "should not be seen as a social reformer", because his concern was "to reform individuals, help them to leave society forever, not to reform the world... he never preached against social inequality".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-497">[451]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-507"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-507">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFlood2008">Flood 2008</a>, pp. 273–274: "The second half of the first millennium BCE was the period that created many of the ideological and institutional elements that characterise later Indian religions. The renouncer tradition played a central role during this formative period of Indian religious history [...] Some of the fundamental values and beliefs that we generally associate with Indian religions in general and Hinduism in particular were in part the creation of the renouncer tradition. These include the two pillars of Indian theologies: samsara - the belief that life in this world is one of suffering and subject to repeated deaths and births (rebirth); moksa/nirvana - the goal of human existence."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-516"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-516">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[a] According to Richard King, Radhakrishnan was a representative of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">Neo-Vedanta</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup> which had a specific understanding of Indian religions: "The inclusivist appropriation of other traditions, so characteristic of neo-Vedanta ideology, appears on three basic levels. First, it is apparent in the suggestion that the (Advaita) Vedanta philosophy of Sankara (c. eighth century CE) constitutes the central philosophy of Hinduism. Second, in an Indian context, neo-Vedanta philosophy subsumes Buddhist philosophies in terms of its own Vedantic ideology. The Buddha becomes a member of the Vedanta tradition, merely attempting to reform it from within. Finally, at a global level, neo-Vedanta colonises the religious traditions of the world by arguing for the centrality of a non-dualistic position as the <i>philosophia perennis</i> underlying all cultural differences.";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_80-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-80">[67]</a></sup><br/>
[b] see <a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">Anatta</a> for further discussion on "no-self" doctrine of Buddhism and its disagreements with the Upanishads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEliot2003Chapter_11:_Rebirth_and_the_Nature_of_the_Soul_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEliot2003Chapter_11:_Rebirth_and_the_Nature_of_the_Soul-515">[467]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Samuel-northsouth-518"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Samuel-northsouth_518-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSamuel2010">Samuel 2010</a>, pp. 193–228, 339–353, specifically pp. 76–79 and 194–199</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-537"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-537">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Axel Michaels mentions the <a href="/wiki/Durga_temple,_Aihole" title="Durga temple, Aihole">Durga temple in Aihole</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Dashavatara_Temple,_Deogarh" title="Dashavatara Temple, Deogarh">Visnu Temple in Deogarh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440_535-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440-535">[484]</a></sup> George Michell notes that earlier temples were built of timber, brick and plaster, while the first stone temples appeared during the period of Gupta rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichell197718_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell197718-536">[485]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-573"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-573">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See also <a class="external text" href="http://www.aurangzeb.info/" rel="nofollow">"Aurangzeb, as he was according to Mughal Records"</a>; more links at the bottom of that page. For Muslim historian's record on major Hindu temple destruction campaigns, from 1193 to 1729 AD, see Richard Eaton (2000), Temple Desecration and Indo-Muslim States, Journal of Islamic Studies, Vol. 11, Issue 3, pages 283-319</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-582"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-582">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to <a href="#CITEREFEaton1993">Eaton (1993</a>, Chapter 5), "in the subcontinent as a whole there is an inverse relationship between the degree of Muslim political penetration and the degree of Islamization." These numbers rule out the possibility of "conversion of the sword." It was the areas which had been least exposed to the Brahmanical fold which showed the largest numbers of Muslims.<br/>
<br/>
Forced conversion did happen, though. According to <a href="#CITEREFMalik2008">Malik (2008</a>, p. 186) forced conversion of tribes occurred between the 10th and the 14th century, and "[f]orced conversions occurred on an even larger scale at the end of the eighteenth century in the context of increased communal conflicts as well as during the <a href="/wiki/Malabar_rebellion" title="Malabar rebellion">Mappila Rebellion</a> (1921/1922)," and according to <a href="#CITEREFEsposito2003">Esposito (2003</a>, p. 303) the orthodox Sufi Islam group <a href="/wiki/Suhrawardiyya" title="Suhrawardiyya">Suhrawardiyya</a> "supported the forced conversion of Hindus and Buddhists."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-595"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-595">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBurley2007">Burley (2007</a>, p. 34): notes the tendency of "a blurring of philosophical distinctions." <a href="#CITEREFLorenzen2006">Lorenzen (2006</a>, pp. 24–33) locates the origins of a distinct Hindu identity in the interaction between Muslims and Hindus, and a process of "mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim other" (p. 27), which started well before 1800 (pp. 26-27). <a href="#CITEREFNicholson2010">Nicholson (2010</a>, p. 2) states that both the Indian and the European thinkers who developed the term <i>Hinduism</i> in the 19th century were influenced by these philosophers.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-614"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-614">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This conjunction of nationalism and religion is not unique to India. The complexities of Asian nationalism are to be seen and understood in the context of colonialism, modernization and <a href="/wiki/Nation-building" title="Nation-building">nation-building</a>. See, for example, <a href="/wiki/Anagarika_Dharmapala" title="Anagarika Dharmapala">Anagarika Dharmapala</a>, for the role of Theravada Buddhism in Sri Lankese struggle for independence,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcMahan2008_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcMahan2008-611">[553]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D.T._Suzuki" title="D.T. Suzuki">D.T. Suzuki</a>, who conjuncted <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a> to <a href="/wiki/Nihonjinron" title="Nihonjinron">Japanese nationalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bushido" title="Bushido">militarism</a>, in defense against both western hegemony <i>and</i> the pressure on Japanese Zen during the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a> to conform to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shinbutsu_Bunri" title="Shinbutsu Bunri">Shinbutsu Bunri</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharf1993_612-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharf1993-612">[554]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharf1995_613-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharf1995-613">[555]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-neo-616"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-neo_616-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Neo-Vedanta also contributed to Hindutva ideology, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_politics" title="Hindu politics">Hindu politics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Communalism_(South_Asia)" title="Communalism (South Asia)">communalism</a>. Yet, Rinehart emphasises that it is "clear that there isn't a neat line of causation that leads from the philosophies of Rammohan Roy, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vivekananda" title="Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a> and Radhakrishnan to the agenda of [...] militant Hindus."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart2004198_615-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart2004198-615">[556]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-644"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-644">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The controversy started as an intense polemic battle between Christian missionaries and Muslim organizations in the first half of the 19th century, where missionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Karl_Gottlieb_Pfander" title="Karl Gottlieb Pfander">Karl Gottlieb Pfander</a> tried to convert Muslims and Hindus, by criticizing Qur'an and Hindu scriptures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ayeshajalal_640-1"><a href="#cite_note-ayeshajalal-640">[569]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641"><a href="#cite_note-641">[570]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-642"><a href="#cite_note-642">[571]</a></sup> Muslim leaders responded by publishing in Muslim-owned newspapers of Bengal, and through rural campaign, polemics against Christians and Hindus, and by launching "purification and reform movements" within Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rafiuddinahmed_639-1"><a href="#cite_note-rafiuddinahmed-639">[568]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ayeshajalal_640-2"><a href="#cite_note-ayeshajalal-640">[569]</a></sup> Hindu leaders joined the proselytization debate, criticized Christianity and Islam, and asserted Hinduism to be a universal, secular religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rafiuddinahmed_639-2"><a href="#cite_note-rafiuddinahmed-639">[568]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csadcock_643-0"><a href="#cite_note-csadcock-643">[572]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<p><i>Subnotes</i></p>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-91">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ghurye: He [Hutton] considers modern Hinduism to be the result of an amalgam between pre-Aryan Indian beliefs of Mediterranean inspiration and the religion of the Rigveda. "The Tribal religions present, as it were, surplus material not yet built into the temple of Hinduism".(<a href="#CITEREFGhurye1980">Ghurye 1980</a>, p. 4)</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tyler, in <i>India: An Anthropological Perspective</i>(1973), page 68, as quoted by Sjoberg, calls Hinduism a "synthesis" in which the Dravidian elements prevail: "The Hindu synthesis was less the dialectical reduction of orthodoxy and heterodoxy than the resurgence of the ancient, aboriginal Indus civilization. In this process the rude, barbaric Aryan tribes were gradually civilised and eventually merged with the autochthonous Dravidians. Although elements of their domestic cult and ritualism were jealously preserved by Brahman priests, the body of their culture survived only in fragmentary tales and allegories embedded in vast, syncretistic compendia. On the whole, the Aryan contribution to Indian culture is insignificant. The essential pattern of Indian culture was already established in the third millennium B.C., and ... the form of Indian civilization perdured and eventually reasserted itself. (<a href="#CITEREFSjoberg1990">Sjoberg 1990</a>, p. 43)</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Hopfe-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hopfe_95-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHopfeWoodward2008">Hopfe &amp; Woodward 2008</a>, p. 79: "The religion that the Aryans brought with them mingled with the religion of the native people, and the culture that developed between them became classical Hinduism."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sweetman cites Richard King (1999) p.128.(<a href="#CITEREFKing1999">King 1999</a>)</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-132">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sweetman cites Dirks (2001), <i>Castes of Mind: Colonialism and the Making of Modern India</i>, Princeton University Press, p. xxvii</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-135">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sweetman cites Viswanathan (2003), <i>Colonialism and the Construction of Hinduism</i>, p.26</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-423"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-423">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Smart distinguishes "Brahmanism" from the Vedic religion, connecting "Brahmanism" with the Upanishads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmart200352.2C_83-86_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmart200352.2C_83-86-422">[388]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>
</div>
</div>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott19985.2C_Quote:_.22Many_describe_Hinduism_as_.27.27sanatana_dharma.27.27.2C_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_orgins_lie_beyond_human_history.22-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott19985.2C_Quote:_.22Many_describe_Hinduism_as_.27.27sanatana_dharma.27.27.2C_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_orgins_lie_beyond_human_history.22_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKnott1998">Knott 1998</a>, pp. 5, Quote: "Many describe Hinduism as <i>sanatana dharma</i>, the eternal tradition or religion. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-9"><sup><i><b>j</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-10"><sup><i><b>k</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLarson2009">Larson 2009</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_18-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMichaels2004">Michaels 2004</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Zaehner, R. C. (1992). <i>Hindu Scriptures</i>. Penguin Random House. pp. 1–7. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0679410782" title="Special:BookSources/978-0679410782">978-0679410782</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+C.&amp;rft.aulast=Zaehner&amp;rft.btitle=Hindu+Scriptures&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0679410782&amp;rft.pages=1-7&amp;rft.pub=Penguin+Random+House&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-:0-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:0_20-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:0_20-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Klostermaier, Klaus (2007). <i>A Survey of Hinduism</i> (3rd ed.). State University of New York Press. pp. 46–52, 76–77. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0791470824" title="Special:BookSources/978-0791470824">978-0791470824</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Klaus&amp;rft.aulast=Klostermaier&amp;rft.btitle=A+Survey+of+Hinduism&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0791470824&amp;rft.pages=46-52%2C+76-77&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-frazierintrop2-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-frazierintrop2_21-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Frazier, Jessica (2011). <i>The Continuum companion to Hindu studies</i>. <li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">O'Conell, Joseph T. (1973). "The Word 'Hindu' in Gauḍīya Vaiṣṇava Texts". <i>Journal of the American Oriental Society</i>. <b>93</b> (3). pp. 340–344. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.2307%2F599467" rel="nofollow">10.2307/599467</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=The+Word+%27Hindu%27+in+Gau%E1%B8%8D%C4%ABya+Vai%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%87ava+Texts&amp;rft.au=O%27Conell%2C+Joseph+T.&amp;rft.date=1973&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+American+Oriental+Society&amp;rft.pages=340-344&amp;rft.volume=93&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F599467&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-50">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Will Sweetman (2003), Mapping Hinduism: 'Hinduism' and the Study of Indian Religions, 1600-1776, Otto Harrassowitz Verlag, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/3-931479498" title="Special:BookSources/3-931479498">3-931479498</a>, pages 163, 154-168</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Julius_J._Lipner" title="Julius J. Lipner">Julius J. Lipner</a> (2009), Hindus: Their Religious Beliefs and Practices, 2nd Edition, Routledge, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-45677-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-45677-7">978-0-415-45677-7</a>, page 8; Quote: "(...) one need not be religious in the minimal sense described to be accepted as a Hindu by Hindus, or describe oneself perfectly validly as Hindu. One may be polytheistic or monotheistic, monistic or pantheistic, even an agnostic, humanist or atheist, and still be considered a Hindu."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lester Kurtz (Ed.), Encyclopedia of Violence, Peace and Conflict, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0123695031" title="Special:BookSources/978-0123695031">978-0123695031</a>, Academic Press, 2008</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">MK Gandhi, <a class="external text" href="http://www.mkgandhi.org/ebks/essence_of_hinduism.pdf" rel="nofollow">The Essence of Hinduism</a>, Editor: VB Kher, Navajivan Publishing, see page 3; According to Gandhi, "a man may not believe in God and still call himself a Hindu."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Knott, Kim (1998). <i>Hinduism: A Very Short Introduction</i>. <li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Patrick Olivelle (2014), The Early Upanisads, Oxford University Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0195352429" title="Special:BookSources/978-0195352429">978-0195352429</a>, page 3; <b>Quote</b>: "Even though theoretically the whole of Vedic corpus is accepted as revealed truth [shruti], in reality it is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a> that have continued to influence the life and thought of the various religious traditions that we have come to call Hindu. Upanishads are the scriptures par excellence of Hinduism".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Wendy Doniger (1990), Textual Sources for the Study of Hinduism, 1st Edition, University of Chicago Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0226618470" title="Special:BookSources/978-0226618470">978-0226618470</a>, pages 2-3; <b>Quote:</b> "The Upanishads supply the basis of later Hindu philosophy; they alone of the Vedic corpus are widely known and quoted by most well-educated Hindus, and their central ideas have also become a part of the spiritual arsenal of rank-and-file Hindus."</span></li>
