<li id="cite_note-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-146">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/dharma.aspx#1" rel="nofollow">The Oxford Dictionary of World Religions, <i>Dharma</i></a>, The <a href="/wiki/Oxford_Dictionary_of_World_Religions" title="Oxford Dictionary of World Religions">Oxford Dictionary of World Religions</a>: "In Hinduism, dharma is a fundamental concept, referring to the order and custom which make life and a universe possible, and thus to the behaviours appropriate to the maintenance of that order."</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw-218"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw_218-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFReichenbach1989">Reichenbach, Bruce R. (April 1989), <a class="external text" href="http://ccbs.ntu.edu.tw/FULLTEXT/JR-PHIL/reiche2.htm" rel="nofollow">"Karma, causation, and divine intervention"</a>, <i>Philosophy East and West</i>, Hawaii: University of Hawaii Press, <b>39</b> (2): 135–149 [145], <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.2307%2F1399374" rel="nofollow">10.2307/1399374</a><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 December</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=Karma%2C+causation%2C+and+divine+intervention&amp;rft.aufirst=Bruce+R.&amp;rft.aulast=Reichenbach&amp;rft.date=1989-04&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.jtitle=Philosophy+East+and+West&amp;rft.pages=135-149+145&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fccbs.ntu.edu.tw%2FFULLTEXT%2FJR-PHIL%2Freiche2.htm&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F1399374&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-219">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFRajadhyaksha1959">Rajadhyaksha (1959), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ihkRAQAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>The six systems of Indian philosophy</i></a>, p. 95, <q>Under the circumstances God becomes an unnecessary metaphysical assumption. Naturally the Sankhyakarikas do not mention God, Vachaspati interprets this as rank atheism.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Rajadhyaksha&amp;rft.btitle=The+six+systems+of+Indian+philosophy&amp;rft.date=1959&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=95&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DihkRAQAAIAAJ&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-220"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-220">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Harold_Coward" title="Harold Coward">Coward, Harold</a> (February 2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LkE_8uch5P0C" rel="nofollow"><i>The perfectibility of human nature in eastern and western thought</i></a>. p. 114. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-7336-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-7336-8">978-0-7914-7336-8</a>. <q>For the Mimamsa the ultimate reality is nothing other than the eternal words of the Vedas. They did not accept the existence of a single supreme creator god, who might have composed the Veda. According to the Mimamsa, gods named in the Vedas have no existence apart from the mantras that speak their names. The power of the gods, then, is nothing other than the power of the mantras that name them.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Harold&amp;rft.aulast=Coward&amp;rft.btitle=The+perfectibility+of+human+nature+in+eastern+and+western+thought&amp;rft.date=2008-02&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7914-7336-8&amp;rft.pages=114&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLkE_8uch5P0C&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-samkhyaatheism-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-samkhyaatheism_221-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSen_Gupta1986">Sen Gupta 1986</a>, p. viii</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-223">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFNeville2001">Neville, Robert (2001), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ThLR13JpCWsC" rel="nofollow"><i>Religious truth</i></a>, p. 51, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-4778-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-4778-9">978-0-7914-4778-9</a>, <q>Mimamsa theorists (theistic and atheistic) decided that the evidence allegedly proving the existence of God was insufficient. They also thought there was no need to postulate a maker for the world, just as there was no need for an author to compose the Veda or an independent God to validate the Vedic rituals.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.aulast=Neville&amp;rft.btitle=Religious+truth&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7914-4778-9&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DThLR13JpCWsC&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>

R Collins (2000), The sociology of philosophies, Harvard University Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0674001879" title="Special:BookSources/978-0674001879">978-0674001879</a>, page 836</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-263">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> to <i>Brihad Aranyaka Upanishad</i> at pages 1-5; <b>Quote</b> - "The Vedas are divided in two parts, the first is the karma-kanda, the ceremonial part, also (called) purva-kanda, and treats on ceremonies; the second part is the jnana kanda, the part which contains knowledge, also named uttara-kanda or posterior part, and unfolds the knowledge of Brahma or the universal soul."</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-wendydoniger-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-wendydoniger_267-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-wendydoniger_267-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Wendy Doniger (1990), Textual Sources for the Study of Hinduism, 1st Edition, University of Chicago Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0226618470" title="Special:BookSources/978-0226618470">978-0226618470</a>, pages 2-3; <b>Quote:</b> "The Upanishads supply the <b>basis of later Hindu philosophy</b>; they alone of the Vedic corpus are widely known and quoted by most well-educated Hindus, and their central ideas have also become a part of the spiritual arsenal of rank-and-file Hindus."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-268">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Wiman Dissanayake (1993), Self as Body in Asian Theory and Practice (Editors: Thomas P. <li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Patrick_Olivelle" title="Patrick Olivelle">Patrick Olivelle</a> (2014), The Early Upanisads, Oxford University Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0195352429" title="Special:BookSources/978-0195352429">978-0195352429</a>, page 3; <b>Quote</b>: "Even though theoretically the whole of vedic corpus is accepted as revealed truth [shruti], in reality it is the Upanishads that have continued to influence the life and thought of the various religious traditions that we have come to call Hindu. Upanishads are the scriptures par excellence of Hinduism".</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-329">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Ariel Glucklich (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KtLScrjrWiAC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Strides of Vishnu : Hindu Culture in Historical Perspective: Hindu Culture in Historical Perspective</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Radhakrishnan-368"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Radhakrishnan_368-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFRadhakrishnan1929"><a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan, S</a> (1929), <i>Indian Philosophy, Volume 1</i>, Muirhead library of philosophy (2nd ed.), London: George Allen and Unwin Ltd., p. 148</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=S&amp;rft.aulast=Radhakrishnan&amp;rft.btitle=Indian+Philosophy%2C+Volume+1&amp;rft.date=1929&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=148&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=George+Allen+and+Unwin+Ltd.&amp;rft.series=Muirhead+library+of+philosophy&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-369"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-369">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">ahiṃsā</span></i> as one of the "emerging ethical and religious issues" in the <span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">Mahābhārata</span> see: Brockington, John, "The Sanskrit Epics", in Flood (2003), p. 125.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-370"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-370">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For text of Y.S. 2.29 and translation of <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:normal; text-decoration: none" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration">yama</span></i> as "vow of self-restraint", see: <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFTaimni1961"><a href="/wiki/I._K._Taimni" title="I. K. Taimni">Taimni, I. K.</a> (1961), <i>The Science of Yoga</i>, Adyar, India: The Theosophical Publishing House, p. 206, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/81-7059-212-7" title="Special:BookSources/81-7059-212-7">81-7059-212-7</a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=I.+K.&amp;rft.aulast=Taimni&amp;rft.btitle=The+Science+of+Yoga&amp;rft.date=1961&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=81-7059-212-7&amp;rft.pages=206&amp;rft.place=Adyar%2C+India&amp;rft.pub=The+Theosophical+Publishing+House&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-veg-371"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-veg_371-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Surveys studying food habits of Indians include: <a class="external text" href="http://www.fao.org/WAIRDOCS/LEAD/X6170E/x6170e09.htm#TopOfPage" rel="nofollow">"Diary and poultry sector growth in India"</a>, Quote:"<b>An analysis of consumption data originating from National Sample Survey (NSS) shows that 42 percent of households are vegetarian, in that they never eat fish, meat or eggs. The remaining 58 percent of households are less strict vegetarians or non-vegetarians.</b>" <a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5hhnKqQ44?url=http://www.fas.usda.gov/htp/highlights/2001/india.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Indian consumer patterns"</a> and <a class="external text" href="http://www.ers.usda.gov/amberwaves/February04/Features/ElephantJogs.htm" rel="nofollow">"Agri reform in India"</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061228214808/http://www.ers.usda.gov/amberwaves/february04/features/elephantjogs.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 28 December 2006 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>.. Results indicate that Indians who eat meat do so infrequently with less than 30% consuming non-vegetarian foods regularly, although the reasons may be economical. <cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150626135438/http://www.fao.org/WAIRDOCS/LEAD/X6170E/x6170e09.htm#TopOfPage" rel="nofollow">"Archived copy"</a>. Archived from the original on 26 June 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 December</span> 2006</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.btitle=Archived+copy&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fao.org%2FWAIRDOCS%2FLEAD%2FX6170E%2Fx6170e09.htm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">CS1 maint: BOT: original-url status unknown (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_BOT:_original-url_status_unknown" title="Category:CS1 maint: BOT: original-url status unknown">link</a>)</span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-372">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Neville Gregory and Temple Grandin (2007), Animal Welfare and Meat Production, CABI, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1845932152" title="Special:BookSources/978-1845932152">978-1845932152</a>, pages 206-208</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-387"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-387">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFGouyon_AnneBumi_Kita_Yayasan2005">Gouyon Anne; Bumi Kita Yayasan (30 September 2005), "The Hidden Life of Bali", <a class="external text" href="http://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/welcome.jsp?action=search&amp;type=isbn&amp;term=9793780002" rel="nofollow"><i>The natural guide to Bali: enjoy nature, meet the people, make a difference</i></a>, Equinox Publishing (Asia) Pte Ltd, p. 51, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/979-3780-00-2" title="Special:BookSources/979-3780-00-2">979-3780-00-2</a><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 August</span> 2010</span></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=The+Hidden+Life+of+Bali&amp;rft.au=Bumi+Kita+Yayasan&amp;rft.au=Gouyon+Anne&amp;rft.btitle=The+natural+guide+to+Bali%3A+enjoy+nature%2C+meet+the+people%2C+make+a+difference&amp;rft.date=2005-09-30&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.isbn=979-3780-00-2&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft.pub=Equinox+Publishing+%28Asia%29+Pte+Ltd&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbookshop.blackwell.co.uk%2Fjsp%2Fwelcome.jsp%3Faction%3Dsearch%26type%3Disbn%26term%3D9793780002&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-388">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Paul Gwynne (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tdsRKc_knZoC&amp;pg=RA5-PT75" rel="nofollow"><i>World Religions in Practice: A Comparative Introduction</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-389"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-389">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">HS Olcott (1906). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jKBVAAAAYAAJ&amp;pg=PA146" rel="nofollow"><i>The Theosophist</i></a>. XXVII. Theosophical Publishing House. pp. 146 with footnote.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=HS+Olcott&amp;rft.btitle=The+Theosophist&amp;rft.date=1906&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=146+with+footnote&amp;rft.pub=Theosophical+Publishing+House&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DjKBVAAAAYAAJ%26pg%3DPA146&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span>, Quote: "It is well known that Vaishnavas abhor animal sacrifice. In this province, like nearly all Bengalis, they celebrate Durga Puja, but their ceremonies are bloodless".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101-102.2C_Quote:_.22Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point.2C_.28.2C.2C.2C.29_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism.27s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._.28....29_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation.2C_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism.2C_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes.22.-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101-102.2C_Quote:_.22Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point.2C_.28.2C.2C.2C.29_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism.27s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._.28....29_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation.2C_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism.2C_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes.22._390-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFuller2004">Fuller 2004</a>, pp. 101-102, Quote: "Blood sacrifice was a clear case in point, (,,,) sacrifice was a barbarity inconsistent with Hinduism's central tenet of non-violence. (...) Contemporary opposition to animal sacrifice rests on an old foundation, although it also stems from the very widespread influence of reformism, whose antipathy to ritual killing has spread well beyond the self-consciously nationalist political classes"..</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-391"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-391">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Andrew J. Nicholson (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fv4rtMlLv3kC" rel="nofollow"><i>Unifying Hinduism: Philosophy and Identity in Indian Intellectual History</i></a>. Columbia University Press. p. 169. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-14986-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-14986-0">978-0-231-14986-0</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Andrew+J.+Nicholson&amp;rft.btitle=Unifying+Hinduism%3A+Philosophy+and+Identity+in+Indian+Intellectual+History&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-14986-0&amp;rft.pages=169&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dfv4rtMlLv3kC&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span>, Quote: "The acceptance of the principle of nonviolence has been so through that animal sacrifice among Hindus today is uncommon, and many Indians are of the opinion that such things as cow slaughter were never practiced in ancient India".</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-497"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_497-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Christopher S. <li id="cite_note-499"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-499">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Hajime Nakamura (1983). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=asNLliQHDNQC" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Early Vedānta Philosophy</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 102–104, 264–269, 294–295. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1">978-81-208-0651-1</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Hajime+Nakamura&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Early+Ved%C4%81nta+Philosophy&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-0651-1&amp;rft.pages=102-104%2C+264-269%2C+294-295&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DasNLliQHDNQC&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span>; Quote: "But the Upanishadic ultimate meaning of the Vedas, was, from the viewpoint of the Vedic canon in general, clearly a new idea.."; p.95: The [oldest] Upanishads in particular were part of the Vedic corpus (...) When these various new ideas were brought together and edited, they were added on to the already existing Vedic..."; p.294: "When early Jainism came into existence, various ideas mentioned in the extant older Upanishads were current,....".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-500"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-500">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Klaus G. Witz (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2jnPlEqwe_UC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Supreme Wisdom of the Upaniṣads: An Introduction</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 23, 1–2. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5">978-81-208-1573-5</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Klaus+G.+Witz&amp;rft.btitle=The+Supreme+Wisdom+of+the+Upani%E1%B9%A3ads%3A+An+Introduction&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-1573-5&amp;rft.pages=23%2C+1-2&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2jnPlEqwe_UC&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span>;<b>Quote</b>: "In the <a href="/wiki/Aranyaka" title="Aranyaka">Aranyakas</a> therefore, thought and inner spiritual awareness started to separate subtler, deeper aspects from the context of ritual performance and myth with which they had been united up to then. This process was then carried further and brought to completion in the Upanishads. (...) The knowledge and attainment of the Highest Goal had been there from the Vedic times. But in the Upanishads inner awareness, aided by major intellectual breakthroughs, arrived at a language in which Highest Goal could be dealt with directly, independent of ritual and sacred lore".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-501"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-501">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Christoph Wulf (2016). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=_ZxeCwAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Exploring Alterity in a Globalized World</i></a>. Routledge. pp. 125–126. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-33113-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-33113-1">978-1-317-33113-1</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Christoph+Wulf&amp;rft.btitle=Exploring+Alterity+in+a+Globalized+World&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-33113-1&amp;rft.pages=125-126&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D_ZxeCwAAQBAJ&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span>; Quote: "(...) the simultaneous emergence of a Vedic and a non-Vedic asceticism. (...) Thus, the challenge for old Vedic views consisted of a new theology, written down in the early Upanishads like the Brhadaranyaka and the Mundaka Upanishad. The new set of ideas contained the...."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-502"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-502">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Jonathan H. X. Lee; Fumitaka Matsuoka; Edmond Yee, Ronald Y. Nakasone (2015). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=taNZCgAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Asian American Religious Cultures</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. pp. 433–434. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-331-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-331-6">978-1-59884-331-6</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Edmond+Yee%2C+Ronald+Y.+Nakasone&amp;rft.au=Fumitaka+Matsuoka&amp;rft.au=Jonathan+H.+X.+Lee&amp;rft.btitle=Asian+American+Religious+Cultures&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59884-331-6&amp;rft.pages=433-434&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DtaNZCgAAQBAJ&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129-503"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_503-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_503-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFShults2014">Shults 2014</a>, p. 125-129.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-World_Religions-504"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-World_Religions_504-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-World_Religions_504-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFNeusner2009">Neusner, Jacob (2009), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=34vGv_HDGG8C&amp;pg=PA183" rel="nofollow"><i>World Religions in America: An Introduction</i></a>, Westminster John Knox Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-664-23320-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-664-23320-4">978-0-664-23320-4</a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacob&amp;rft.aulast=Neusner&amp;rft.btitle=World+Religions+in+America%3A+An+Introduction&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-664-23320-4&amp;rft.pub=Westminster+John+Knox+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D34vGv_HDGG8C%26pg%3DPA183&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-505"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-505">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFMeltonBaumann2010">Melton, J. Gordon; Baumann, Martin (2010), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&amp;pg=PA1324" rel="nofollow"><i>Religions of the World, Second Edition: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices</i></a>, ABC-CLIO, p. 1324, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-204-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59884-204-3">978-1-59884-204-3</a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Baumann%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aufirst=J.+Gordon&amp;rft.aulast=Melton&amp;rft.btitle=Religions+of+the+World%2C+Second+Edition%3A+A+Comprehensive+Encyclopedia+of+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59884-204-3&amp;rft.pages=1324&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dv2yiyLLOj88C%26pg%3DPA1324&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199681-82-506"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199681-82_506-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFlood1996">Flood 1996</a>, pp. 81-82.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTERaju199242-508"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaju199242_508-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRaju1992">Raju 1992</a>, p. 42.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-509"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-509">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">KN Jayatilleke (2010), Early Buddhist Theory of Knowledge, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-8120806191" title="Special:BookSources/978-8120806191">978-8120806191</a>, pages 246-249, from note 385 onwards;<br/>
Steven Collins (1994), Religion and Practical Reason (Editors: Frank Reynolds, David Tracy), State Univ of New York Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0791422175" title="Special:BookSources/978-0791422175">978-0791422175</a>, page 64; Quote: "Central to Buddhist soteriology is the doctrine of not-self (Pali: anattā, Sanskrit: anātman, the opposed doctrine of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātman</a> is central to Brahmanical thought). Put very briefly, this is the [Buddhist] doctrine that human beings have no soul, no self, no unchanging essence.";<br/>
Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA2" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i>, p. 2, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a>, pages 2-4<br/>
Katie Javanaud (2013), <a class="external text" href="https://philosophynow.org/issues/97/Is_The_Buddhist_No-Self_Doctrine_Compatible_With_Pursuing_Nirvana" rel="nofollow">Is The Buddhist 'No-Self' Doctrine Compatible With Pursuing Nirvana?</a>, Philosophy Now</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-510"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-510">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">John C. Plott et al (2000), Global History of Philosophy: The Axial Age, Volume 1, Motilal Banarsidass, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-8120801585" title="Special:BookSources/978-8120801585">978-8120801585</a>, page 63, Quote: "The Buddhist schools reject any Ātman concept. As we have already observed, this is the basic and ineradicable distinction between Hinduism and Buddhism".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-511"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-511">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For the impact of "soul exists" concept in later Hinduism, see Edward Roer (Translator), <i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3uwDAAAAMAAJ&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow">Shankara's Introduction</a></i>, p. 3, at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a> to <i>Brihad Aranyaka Upanishad</i> at pages 3-4; Quote - "(...) Lokayatikas and Bauddhas who assert that the soul does not exist. There are four sects among the followers of Buddha: 1. Madhyamicas who maintain all is void; 2. Yogacharas, who assert except sensation and intelligence all else is void; 3. Sautranticas, who affirm actual existence of external objects no less than of internal sensations; 4. Vaibhashikas, who agree with later (Sautranticas) except that they contend for immediate apprehension of exterior objects through images or forms represented to the intellect."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-512"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-512">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Richard King (1995), Ācārya, Gauḍapāda - Early Advaita Vedānta and Buddhism: the Mahāyāna context of the Gauḍapādīya-kārikā, SUNY Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2513-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2513-8">978-0-7914-2513-8</a>, pages 51-58</span></li>

<cite class="citation book">C. J. <li id="cite_note-559"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-559">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://faculty.washington.edu/kpotter/ckeyt/txt2.htm" rel="nofollow">Texts &amp; Manuscripts - 5th to 9th Century Indian philosophies</a> Karl Potter (2015), University of Washington</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680-560"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680_560-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFNakamura2004">Nakamura 2004</a>, p. 680.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985-561"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985_561-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGaborieau1985">Gaborieau 1985</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140-562"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140_562-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFNovetzke2013">Novetzke 2013</a>, p. 138-140.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995110-563"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995110_563-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLarson1995">Larson 1995</a>, p. 110, quoting Peter Hardy</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62-564"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62_564-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEaton2000a">Eaton 2000a</a>, p. 62: "A dangerously plausible picture of fanaticism, vandalism and villainy on the part of the Indo-Muslim conquerors and rulers" has been built up in recent times. "This picture has been based largely on Persian material first translated by the British rulers, and used to create a favourable comparison of the British rule with their Islamic predecessors."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16.2C_61-62.2C_172-174-565"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16.2C_61-62.2C_172-174_565-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWink1991">Wink 1991</a>, p. 14-16, 61-62, 172-174(p. 62) Their [slaves who were Sindians and Indians] number can only be guessed but was not large and definitely was dwarfed by the export of slaves from India during the Ghaznavid and Ghurid raids in northern India in the eleventh to thirteenth centuries." "From the Kanauj campaign of 1018 until the establishment of the Delhi Sultanate by Aybak in 1206 a vast stream of perhaps more than several hundred thousands of Indian slaves reached Ghazna, and hence were traced to other parts of the Islamic world. In the thirteenth century Delhi developed into a considerable slave market. (...) Timur's capture of Delhi in 1398-9 provided the last massive haul of Hindu slaves by an invader, and after the fourteenth century slavery in India generally declined in scale."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12-566"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12_566-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-12_566-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEaton2006">Eaton 2006</a>, pp. 11-12.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199162-567"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199162_567-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWink1991">Wink 1991</a>, p. 62.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-568"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611_568-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEaton2006">Eaton 2006</a>, p. 11: "In 1562 <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a> abolished the practice of enslaving the families of war captives; his son Jahangir banned sending of slaves from Bengal as tribute in lieu of cash, which had been the custom since the 14th century. These measures notwithstanding, the Mughals actively participated in slave trade with Central Asia, deporting rebels and subjects who had defaulted on revenue payments, following precedents inherited from Delhi Sultanate".</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118-569"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118_569-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGrapperhaus2009">Grapperhaus 2009</a>, p. 118.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271-570"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271_570-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAyalon1986">Ayalon 1986</a>, p. 271.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-571"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-571">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Abraham Eraly (2000), Emperors of the Peacock Throne: The Saga of the Great Mughals, Penguin Books, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0141001432" title="Special:BookSources/978-0141001432">978-0141001432</a>, pages 398-399</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115-572"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115_572-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAvari2013">Avari 2013</a>, p. 115: citing a 2000 study, writes "Aurangzeb was perhaps no more culpable than most of the sultans before him; they desecrated the temples associated with Hindu power, not all temples. It is worth noting that, in contrast to the traditional claim of hundreds of Hindu temples having been destroyed by Aurangzeb, a recent study suggests a modest figure of just fifteen destructions."<br/>
<br/>
In contrast to Avari, the historian Abraham Eraly estimates Aurangzeb era destruction to be significantly higher; "in 1670, all temples around <a href="/wiki/Ujjain" title="Ujjain">Ujjain</a> were destroyed"; and later, "300 temples were destroyed in and around Chitor, <a href="/wiki/Udaipur" title="Udaipur">Udaipur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jaipur" title="Jaipur">Jaipur</a>" among other Hindu temples destroyed elsewhere in campaigns through 1705.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[519]</a></sup><br/>
<br/>
The persecution during the Islamic period targeted non-Hindus as well. Avari writes, "Aurangzeb's religious policy caused friction between him and the ninth <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikh</a> guru, Tegh Bahadur. In both <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a> and Kashmir the <a href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">Sikh</a> leader was roused to action by Aurangzeb's excessively zealous Islamic policies. Seized and taken to Delhi, he was called upon by <a href="/wiki/Aurangzeb" title="Aurangzeb">Aurangzeb</a> to embrace <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and, on refusal, was tortured for five days and then beheaded in November 1675. Two of the ten Sikh gurus thus died as martyrs at the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughals</a>. (Avari (2013), page 155)</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasham1999-574"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasham1999_574-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBasham1999">Basham 1999</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384-575"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384_575-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSmith1999">Smith 1999</a>, p. 381-384.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109-576"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109_576-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLarson1995">Larson 1995</a>, p. 109.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995111-577"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_577-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_577-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLarson1995">Larson 1995</a>, p. 111.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995112-578"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_578-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_578-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLarson1995">Larson 1995</a>, p. 112.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHardy1977-579"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHardy1977_579-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHardy1977">Hardy 1977</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187-580"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187_580-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMalik2008">Malik 2008</a>, p. 183-187.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari201366-70-581"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari201366-70_581-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAvari2013">Avari 2013</a>, pp. 66-70: "Many Hindu slaves converted to Islam and gained their liberty."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-584"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-584">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Mādhava Āchārya". Encyclopædia Britannica.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-talbot-585"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-talbot_585-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Cynthia Talbot (2001), Precolonial India in Practice: Society, Region, and Identity in Medieval Andhra, Oxford University Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0195136616" title="Special:BookSources/978-0195136616">978-0195136616</a>, pages 185–187, 199–201</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-arvindmr-633"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-arvindmr_633-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-arvindmr_633-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-arvindmr_633-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Arvind Sharma (2011), Hinduism as a Missionary Religion, State University of New York Press, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1438432113" title="Special:BookSources/978-1438432113">978-1438432113</a>, pages 31-53</span></li>

Section 3 Southeast Asia, Religions</a></i> at <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">Google Books</a>, pages 1-47</span></li>

<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFVivekjivandas2010">Vivekjivandas (2010), <i>Hinduism: An Introduction - Part 1</i>, Ahmedabad: Swaminarayan Aksharpith, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-7526-433-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-7526-433-5">978-81-7526-433-5</a></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.au=Vivekjivandas&amp;rft.btitle=Hinduism%3A+An+Introduction+-+Part+1&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-7526-433-5&amp;rft.place=Ahmedabad&amp;rft.pub=Swaminarayan+Aksharpith&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-624"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-624">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2009/127364.htm" rel="nofollow">"Bhutan"</a>. <i>U.S. Department of State</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.atitle=Bhutan&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=U.S.+Department+of+State&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.state.gov%2Fg%2Fdrl%2Frls%2Firf%2F2009%2F127364.htm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-627"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-627">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Department of Census and Statistics,<a class="external text" href="http://www.statistics.gov.lk/PopHouSat/CPH2011/index.php?fileName=pop43&amp;gp=Activities&amp;tpl=3" rel="nofollow">The Census of Population and Housing of Sri Lanka-2011</a></span></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<p><b>Introductory</b></p>
<ul>
<li><cite class="citation book">Fowler, Jeaneane D. (1997). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RmGKHu20hA0C" rel="nofollow"><i>Hinduism: Beliefs and Practices</i></a>. Sussex Academic Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-60-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-60-8">978-1-898723-60-8</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeaneane+D.&amp;rft.aulast=Fowler&amp;rft.btitle=Hinduism%3A+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-898723-60-8&amp;rft.pub=Sussex+Academic+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DRmGKHu20hA0C&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFFlood1996"><a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Flood, Gavin D.</a> (1996), <i>An Introduction to Hinduism</i>, Cambridge University Press</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin+D.&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introduction+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
</ul>
<p><b>Origins</b></p>
<ul>
<li><cite class="citation book">Parpola, Asko (2015). <i>The Roots of Hinduism. The Early Aryans and the Indus Civilization</i>. Oxford University Press.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Asko&amp;rft.aulast=Parpola&amp;rft.btitle=The+Roots+of+Hinduism.+The+Early+Aryans+and+the+Indus+Civilization&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation" id="CITEREFSamuel2010">Samuel, Geoffrey (2010), <i>The Origins of Yoga and Tantra. Indic Religions to the Thirteenth Century</i>, Cambridge University Press</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Geoffrey&amp;rft.aulast=Samuel&amp;rft.btitle=The+Origins+of+Yoga+and+Tantra.+Indic+Religions+to+the+Thirteenth+Century&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
</ul>

<li><cite class="citation book" id="CITEREFKlostermaier2007">Klostermaier, Klaus K. (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=E_6-JbUiHB4C" rel="nofollow"><i>A Survey of Hinduism: Third Edition</i></a>. State University of New York Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780791470824" title="Special:BookSources/9780791470824">9780791470824</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Klaus+K.&amp;rft.aulast=Klostermaier&amp;rft.btitle=A+Survey+of+Hinduism%3A+Third+Edition&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=9780791470824&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DE_6-JbUiHB4C&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span></li>
<li><cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Flood, Gavin (Ed)</a> (2003). <i>Blackwell companion to Hinduism</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blackwell_Publishing" title="Blackwell Publishing">Blackwell Publishing</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-631-21535-2" title="Special:BookSources/0-631-21535-2">0-631-21535-2</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AHinduism&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin+%28Ed%29&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.btitle=Blackwell+companion+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-631-21535-2&amp;rft.pub=Blackwell+Publishing&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook"><span style="display:none;"> </span></span><span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">CS1 maint: Extra text: authors list (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Extra_text:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: Extra text: authors list">link</a>)</span></li>

London: Curzon Press. x, 212 p. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7007-0173-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-7007-0173-7">0-7007-0173-7</a></li>

<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.iep.utm.edu/hindu-ph/" rel="nofollow">Hindu Philosophy and Hinduism</a>, IEP, Shyam Ranganathan, York University</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~witzel/vedica.pdf" rel="nofollow">Vedic Hinduism</a> SW Jamison and M Witzel, Harvard University</li>
<li><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Complete_Works_of_Swami_Vivekananda/Volume_1/Lectures_And_Discourses/The_Hindu_Religion" title="wikisource:The Complete Works of Swami Vivekananda/Volume 1/Lectures And Discourses/The Hindu Religion">The Hindu Religion</a>, Swami Vivekananda (1894), Wikisource</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.ramakrishna.org/catalog/archive/Spirit_of_Hinduism.htm" rel="nofollow">Hinduism by Swami Nikhilananda</a>, The Ramakrishna Mission (one of the Theistic Hindu Movements)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.dlshq.org/download/hinduismbk.pdf" rel="nofollow">All About Hinduism by Swami Sivananda (pdf)</a>, The Divine Life Society (one of the Theistic Hindu Movements)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.iep.utm.edu/adv-veda/" rel="nofollow">Advaita Vedanta Hinduism by Sangeetha Menon</a>, IEP (one of the non-Theistic school of Hindu philosophy)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://hinduism.iskcon.com/" rel="nofollow">Heart of Hinduism: An overview of Hindu traditions</a>, ISKCON (Hare Krishna Movement)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/wfchannel/index.php?wfc_cid=21" rel="nofollow">What is Hinduism?</a>, Editors of Hinduism Today Magazine</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.pluralism.org/religion/hinduism/bibliography" rel="nofollow">Hinduism outside India</a>, A Bibliography, Harvard University (The Pluralism Project)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-00196705/" rel="nofollow">What's in a Name? Agama Hindu Bali in the Making - Hinduism in Bali, Indonesia</a> Michel Picard, Le CNRS (Paris, France)</li>
</ul>
<p><b>Research on Hinduism</b></p>
<ul>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.ochs.org.uk/" rel="nofollow">The Oxford Center for Hindu Studies</a>, University of Oxford</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://jhs.oxfordjournals.org/content/current" rel="nofollow">Latest issue of The Journal of Hindu Studies</a>, Oxford University Press</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://link.springer.com/journal/volumesAndIssues/11407" rel="nofollow">Latest issue of the International Journal of Hindu Studies</a>, Springer</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://digitalcommons.butler.edu/jhcs/" rel="nofollow">Latest issue of The Journal of Hindu-Christian Studies</a>, Butler University</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://jewishstudies.fiu.edu/about-us/initiative-for-global-jewish-communities/society-for-indo-judaic-studies/journal-archives/" rel="nofollow">Latest issue of The Journal of Indo-Judaic Studies</a>, Florida International University</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.internationaljournaldharmastudies.com" rel="nofollow">Latest issue of the International Journal of Dharma Studies</a>, Springer (Topical publications on Hinduism, other Indic religions)</li>
</ul>
<p><b>Audio on Hinduism</b></p>
<ul>
<li><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/SwamiVivekanandaSwamiVivekananda1893Speech" rel="nofollow">Hinduism as a Religion, by Swami Vivekananda</a>, <i>World Parliament of Religion</i>, Chicago in 1893 (Audio Version, <a class="external text" href="http://www.parliamentofreligions.org/_includes/FCKcontent/file/Vivekananda.pdf" rel="nofollow">Text</a>)</li>
<li><a class="external text" href="http://www.ochs.org.uk/lectures/previous" rel="nofollow">Scholarly lectures on Hinduism</a>, OCHS, University of Oxford</li>
</ul>

<th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background:#FFC569;;width:1%">Practices</th>
<td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px;background:transparent;">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div>
